description: BioAI is a key enabler of initiatives that integrate artificial intelligence with biology to address complex research challenges through data-driven, cutting-edge, and multidisciplinary approaches. This integration is expected to drive significant advances in drug discovery, genomics and precision medicine, imaging and diagnostics, strain engineering for industrial-scale production of biomaterials and bioproducts, and agricultural innovation. The session highlights the BioAI initiative through a keynote address followed by an expert panel discussion.
speakers: Dr Anand Deshpande, Persistent Systems, Pune; Dr. Anurag Agrawal, Biosciences and Health Research, Ashoka University; Dr. Aravind Penmatsa, IISc Bangalore; Dr. Ashish M Gaikwad, Praj Industries, Pune; Dr. Debasisa Mohanty, BRIC-NII, New Delhi; Dr. Lipi Thukral, IGIB, New Delhi; Dr. Madhura Vipra, Medvolt, Pune; Dr. Manju Tanwar, Organic Recycling Systems, Mumbai; Dr. Rajesh S. Gokhale, DBT/DG BRIC/Chairman BIRAC; Prof. Santanu Chaudhury, School of Advanced Computing, Ashoka University, Haryana
summary_one_liner: BioAI revolutionizing drug discovery, genomics, and precision medicine pipelines
icebreaker: Ask Dr. Rajesh Gokhale which BioAI application will transform drug discovery first in your space?
networking_tip: Deep technical event with biotech investors present: prep 2-3 specific drug discovery use cases to discuss.

title: The AI-DPI Nexus: The Future of Public Interest Technology
description: Global policy discourse largely treats AI and DPI separately. AI discussions focus on model safety, compute governance, workforce displacement. DPI conversations center on digital identity, digital payment, data exchange. AI-DPI convergence can create exponential value and new risk categories. While this convergence accelerates, critical questions remain: How can DPI lower barriers for local AI innovation while preventing new forms of exclusion? How can responsible AI systems be built in resource-constrained environments using DPI approaches?
speakers: Antonio Zaballos, Asian Development Bank; Dr. Olubayo Adekanmbi, Data Science Nigeria; Howard Lakougna, Gates Foundation; Kamya Chandra, CDPI; Kay McGowan, Digital Impact Alliance; Keyzom Ngodup Massally, UNDP Chief Digital Office; Olivier Twagirayezu, Centre for the Fourth Industrial Revolution Rwanda; Seydina Ndiaye, Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI) and the UN High-Level Advisory Body on AI, Senegal; Vyjayanti Desai, World Bank
summary_one_liner: Converging AI and DPI to create exponential public interest value
icebreaker: Ask Vyjayanti Desai how DPI and AI safety discussions should converge—her take on the nexus?
networking_tip: High decision-maker density: Find policy researchers during breaks; they shape future governance frameworks.

title: From Pilots to Impact: Evidence on Scaling AI for Farmers in LMICs
description: This session will host a high-level panel at the AI Impact Summit 2026 to examine what works in AI deployments in Agriculture while being informed by a Multi-Country Landscape Study across Low- and Middle-Income Countries. The panel integrates Evidence, Practice, and Policy, highlighting India's Saagu Baagu system, and addresses Bias, Digital Exclusion, and Responsible Governance. It will frame AI for Agriculture as one of Development and Public and will shed light on challenges and deliver lessons for Responsible Scaling for Smallholders and inclusive agricultural innovation globally.
speakers: Dr. Francis Xavier Rathinam, Athena Infonomics; Dr. Kavya Dashora, IIT Delhi; Dr. Monisha Lakshminarayan, Athena Infonomics; Dr. V . Praveen Rao, Kaveri University; Ms. Deepa Karthekeyan, Athena Infonomics; Ms. Zeba Siddiqui, Athena Infonomics
summary_one_liner: Evidence-based lessons for responsibly scaling agricultural AI in LMICs
icebreaker: Dr. Monisha Lakshminarayan studied what actually scales—ask her: which farm AI pilots proved ROI in LMICs?
networking_tip: Medium crowd of development economists: ask specific questions during Q&A to stand out, then network.

title: AI and Children: Turning Principles into Practice for Safe, Inclusive, and Empowering AI
description: This flagship session bringing together government, industry, academia, youth and multilateral agencies to translate child-centred AI principles into action. Aligned with existing frameworks, the session will examine safety, inclusion, ethics, and governance, showcase practical tools and case studies, amplify youth perspectives, and conclude with concrete commitments, next steps, and a roadmap for sustained collaboration on Responsible AI for children in India.
speakers: Ajay Kumar Sood, GoI; Ajay Vij, Accenture; Gokul V Subramaniam, Intel India, Client Computing Group; Hector de Rivoire, Microsoft; Henrietta Ridley, UNICEF; Prasiddhi Singh, FICCI; Sanjeev Sharma, NCPCR; Thomas Davin, UNICEF Office of Innovation
summary_one_liner: Translating child-centred AI principles into concrete safety commitments
icebreaker: Thomas Davin brought youth voices—ask him what children told the panel about safe AI they actually use.
networking_tip: Multilateral agency leaders here: sit near academics during Q&A, then approach them with implementation insights.

title: Power, Protection, and Progress: Legislators and the AI Era
description: As Artificial Intelligence increasingly influences lawmaking, governance, and public life, Members of Parliament face both new opportunities and heightened risks. From the use of AI in policymaking and constituency engagement to challenges posed by deepfakes, misinformation, and online harassment, this session will focus on how legislators can build digital readiness, strengthen institutional safeguards, and exercise responsible public leadership in the AI era.
speakers: Lord Uday Nagaraju, Future Shift labs Foundation; Sarith Felber, Future Shift Labs Foundation; Shri Lavu Sri Krishna Devarayalu, Future Shift Labs Foundation; Sujeet Kumar, Future Shift Labs Foundation; Ujjwal  Kumar, Future Shifts Labs Foundation
summary_one_liner: Equipping legislators with digital readiness for the AI governance era
icebreaker: Ask Lord Uday Nagaraju: how should MPs prepare for AI-generated deepfakes targeting legislation?
networking_tip: MPs and policy advisors only—come with one concrete AI governance risk from your region; trade insights.

title: Empowering Communities in the Age of Advanced AI: Inclusion and Safety for Sustainable Development
description: As AI becomes central to agriculture, health, social protection, and digital public infrastructure, safety and inclusion extend beyond technical reliability to equity, agency, deception, and power imbalances. This session positions AI safety as essential to sustainable development in the Global South, ensuring technologies respect local contexts and reduce inequality. Participants will examine equity, deception and manipulation risks, and how Global South perspectives can shape proactive, globally relevant AI safety frameworks before large-scale deployment begins worldwide.
speakers: Aditya Gopalan, IISc; Amitabh Nag, FAR.AI; Harsh Dhand, Google; Jagadish Babu, EkStep Foundation; Kalika Bali, Microsoft; Nakul, Wadhwani AI Global; Nidhi Bhasin, Digital Green trust; Saryu Natarajan, Apti Institute; Stuart Russell, University of California, Berkeley
summary_one_liner: AI safety & inclusion for equitable sustainable development in Global South
icebreaker: Ask Kalika Bali how multilingual AI models address safety gaps in underserved communities
networking_tip: Engage Aditya Gopolan on IISc's AI safety research partnerships with Global South institutions

title: Why Startups Fail - Three Design Lenses to Fail Less as an (AI) Startup
description: This session will feature a design-led exploration of why AI startups fail and how founders can de-risk growth using three practical lenses. It will also include a rapid pitch spotlighting a cutting-edge startup building the next generation of autonomous operations.
speakers: Chintan Vaishnav, Researcher, MIT
summary_one_liner: Design patterns to de-risk AI startup growth and reduce failure rates
icebreaker: Chintan, I'm curious how the design lens approach differs from traditional startup risk frameworks.
networking_tip: Connect with other founders post-pitch to discuss de-risking strategies and share failure case studies.

title: The Governance Gap: Designing Global Standards for AI Advisory Boards
description: AI is scaling rapidly across products and borders, yet regulation and transparency remain uncertain—particularly for smaller organizations with limited governance capacity. This session examines the minimum requirements for effective AI governance bodies and how ethical decision-making structures can function across organizations of different sizes. Through discussion and reflection, the session aims to surface shared principles, key challenges, and practical next steps to support responsible, transparent, and globally relevant AI governance.
speakers: Julie Owono, The Oversight Board; Saurabh Karn, Sarvam AI; Sudhir Krishnaswamy, The Oversight Board
summary_one_liner: Setting minimum global standards for effective AI ethics advisory boards
icebreaker: Julie Owono, how do you design advisory boards for organizations that lack governance resources but need transparency?
networking_tip: Corporate Governance Heads make decisions. Sit strategically in middle rows to catch both experts and practitioners.

title: AI for All: India's Policy Architecture for Public-Interest AI and Inclusive Development
description:
How can Public-Interest AI induce a meaningful and inclusive interaction
between policy and society to achieve the vision of Viksit Bharat@2047?
speakers: Dr. Animesh Naskar, Department of Economics, Hansraj College University of Delhi; Dr. Ankit Rajpal, Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi; Dr. Divyam Sharma, Jain Chest Care Center, Jaipur; Dr. Sudeep Raj Kumar, Hindu College, University of Delhi; Dr. Supreet Kaur, Finance and Taxation, University of Delhi; Mr. Ashish Abrol, Indian Revenue Service -Income Tax; Mr. Sudhir Goenka, Autoposting.ai and TinyCheque; Mr. Udit Goenka, TinyCheque; Ms. Sudeshna Mukherjee, UN Women
knowledge_partners: Department of Political Science, University of Delhi
summary_one_liner: Designing India's public-interest AI architecture for Viksit Bharat 2047
icebreaker: Dr. Divyam Sharma, how does Public-Interest AI differ from corporate AI in achieving inclusive development outcomes?
networking_tip: Think Tank Analysts and Gov Officials often sit together. Arrive early to grab seats in the policy practitioner cluster.

title: Unlocking the Future: A Pact Between Tech Giants and the Next Generation
description: Adolescents are engaging with AI more frequently and in increasingly emotional ways during a critical developmental stage that requires specific safeguards, especially in the presence of anthropomorphic design. This panel introduces an international multistakeholder coalition leading global efforts on this issue. It presents early findings from this transdisciplinary initiative, grounded in neuroscience and AI safety research, and highlights the roles and responsibilities of stakeholders in creating beneficial, child-centered, and safe AI
speakers: Adrien Abecassis, Paris Peace Forum, iRAISE; Anne-Sophie Seret, everyone.ai and iRAISE; Dr Mathilde Cerioli, everyone.ai; Lakshmi Pratury, INK talks; Pragya Misra, OpenAI India; Sampurna Behura, India Child Protection; Stuart Russel, University of California/ Berkeley; Vithika Yadav, Youth Representative
summary_one_liner: Neuroscience-backed global coalition protecting youth from anthropomorphic AI risks
icebreaker: Andrew Soltan, how do you balance data sovereignty with the need for global genomic collaboration?
networking_tip: Find researchers tackling similar federated learning challenges—privacy engineers clustered in sessions.

title: The Future of Frontier AI and Cybersecurity
description: This session explores how as AI capabilities in cybersecurity evolve, risk management and testing frameworks are essential to enhance security while addressing emerging threats. Many leading AI firms have signed on to the Frontier AI Safety Commitments, yet questions remain about operationalizing AI-cyber risk management and testing approaches. Speakers from industry, civil society, and academia will explore current offensive cyber threats from AI, evaluation methods and benchmarks, and best practices for mitigating AI-driven cyber risks.
speakers: Adriana Stephan, Frontier Model Forum; Amanda Craig, Microsoft; Amlan Mohanty, CeRAI - IIT Madras; Jonas Kgomo, Equaino Institute; Peter Mattson, MLCommons; Rebecca Finlay, Partnership on AI; Supheakmungkol Sarin, AI Safety Asia
summary_one_liner: Frontier AI safety commitments meet real-world cybersecurity threat management
icebreaker: Peter Mattson, what's the riskiest AI security gap frontier labs still haven't solved in testing frameworks?
networking_tip: CISO Executives and AI Safety Engineers rarely network. Position yourself as the bridge—ask questions connecting both worlds.

title: From Promising Pilots to System Shifts: What It Really Takes to Scale Responsible AI in Education
description: As opposed to theoretical concepts and ideas, this session will share practical insights that are already driving change in education. Panellists will demonstrate how AI can move from pilot to adoption in low- and middle-income countries in under a year.
speakers: Elmo Domino Jose, Education Center for AI Research (E-CAIR); Felicity Rose Burgess, AI Observatory & Brink; Margarita Maria Luz, AI Observatory & Brink; Ranjitsinh Disale, Ranjitsinh Disale Foundation
summary_one_liner: Fast-tracking AI education pilots to nationwide adoption in LMICs
icebreaker: Ranjitsinh Disale, what scaling challenge surprised you most moving education AI from pilot to system-wide adoption?
networking_tip: Impact Investors + Edtech Founders will dominate. Sit near education ministry officials—they control deployment decisions.

title: Responsible AI Hub: Responsible Deployment and Use of AI Systems in Social Welfare Delivery
description: This panel will examine the use of artificial intelligence in social welfare delivery and its implications for accuracy, fairness, and accountability. It will explore risks linked to automated decision making, the importance of human oversight, and ways to reduce unintended negative outcomes to beneficiaries. The discussion will focus on monitoring and evaluation approaches that help governments assess impact, costs, and outcomes, and identify safeguards to ensure transparent, equitable, and effective welfare programmes.
speakers: Abhishek Jain, Straive; Amba Kak, AI Now Institute; Amit Kumar, Fujitsu Consulting India Pvt Ltd; Gabi Leibowitz, ElevenLabs; Gaurav Godhwani, CivicDataLab; Isabel Elbert, United Nations Human Rights B-Tech Project; Jennifer Mulveny, Adobe; Kishore Balaji Desikachari, IBM; Kumar Sambhav Srivastava, NutGraph Social Data Lab; Maya Sherman, Embassy of Israel in India; Prateek Waghre, Tech Global Institute, India; Prof. Balaraman Ravindran, CeRAI; Ryan Carrier, ForHumanity; Sundaraparipurnan Narayanan, AI Tech Ethics
summary_one_liner: Safeguarding welfare beneficiaries from AI-driven automated decision-making risks
icebreaker: Amba Kak, what's the biggest fairness pitfall you've seen in welfare automation that could've been caught earlier?
networking_tip: Target the Civil Society Leaders—they bridge implementation gaps. Catch them during breaks before they network with officials.

title: Policymakers' Dialogue on AI, Policy Evolution, and the Rule of Law
description: This session will explore the Summit's pillar on Democratising AI Resources, exploring the distribution of institutional capacity, legal safeguards, and governance frameworks alongside access to computational infrastructure and datasets. The dialogue will examine how broader access to AI is bolstered by transparent rule-making processes and accountable decision-making. The session will also investigate the development of inclusive regulatory institutions designed to promote shared technological opportunities across countries.
speakers: Dr. Markus Siewert, TUM Think Tank (Munich School of Politics and Public Policy; Dr. Sasmit Patra, Rajya Sabha, India; Ivana Bartoletti, Wipro; Jameela Sahiba, The Dialogue; Mathukumilli Sribharat, Telugu Desam Party (TDP); Mr. Mahaveer Singhvi, Ministry of External Affairs; Mr. Pravin Anand, Anand and Anand (Law Firm); Prof. Dr. Kristina Sinemus, Hessian Ministry of Digitalisation and Innovation
summary_one_liner: Cross-border policymaker dialogue on AI governance and rule of law
icebreaker: Prof. Kristina Sinemus, how are you seeing rule of law evolving differently across regions in AI governance?
networking_tip: Regulatory Body Heads will cluster near policy experts. Position yourself in Q&A zones for direct access to decision-makers.

title: AI That Works: Evaluating Technology for Social Change
description: As AI use cases expand across the social sector, robust evaluation systems are critical to safeguard vulnerable users, improve system performance, and ensure meaningful positive impact. This session addresses the growing need to support development leaders in designing cost-effective AI evaluation pipelines that enhance benefits while minimizing potential harm. It will draw on culturally responsive and context-specific evaluation approaches aimed at improving the safety and reliability of LLMs for diverse, multilingual communities.
speakers: Baarish Aggarwal, Tattle; Edmund Korley, Agency Fund; Poorva Malviya, Noora Health; Vineet Singh, Digital Green; Vinod Rajasekhran, Tech4Dev
summary_one_liner: Building cost-effective AI evaluation pipelines safeguarding vulnerable communities
icebreaker: Poorva Malviya, what's the biggest evaluation gap you're seeing in multilingual AI deployments?
networking_tip: Approach social sector CTOs during Q&A—they're hands-on and eager to discuss evaluation frameworks.

title: NegotiateCOP: Democratizing Global Climate Negotiations through Open-Source AI
description: This session introduces NegotiateCOP, an open AI tool as a digital public good to support international negotiators with the analysis of country positions at COP30. Through a live demonstration and practical insights, the session explores how open AI tools can be used in multilateral negotiations enabling more inclusive, equitable, and evidence-based international cooperation.
speakers: Dr. Iliya Nickelt, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ); Gunda Ehmke (German National), Data Innovation Lab; Hans-Christian Mangelsdorf, German Federal Foreign Office; Yannik Sassmann, Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)
summary_one_liner: Open-source AI tool democratizing climate negotiations for COP30 delegates
icebreaker: Dr. Iliya Nickelt, how did NegotiateCOP actually change country position analysis at COP negotiations?
networking_tip: Climate Negotiators + Foreign Ministry Officials = rare access. Network hard during live demo—they'll gather around tools.

title: Cognitive Infrastructure for Sustainable and Resilient Futures
description: Infrastructure and construction is one of the world's largest industries. It shapes economic development, climate outcomes, and societal well-being, yet remain among the least digitized and least capable of learning from their own history. Critical decisions affecting trillions of dollars are still made with fragmented data and experience trapped in individual silos, limiting collective judgment. This session explores cognitive infrastructure and vertical AI as tools to advance critical thinking...
speakers: Bertrand Badré, Blue like an Orange Sustainable Capital; Dr. Saurabh Mishra, Taiyo.AI; G. Sayeed Choudhury, Carnegie Mellon University; Mihir Kumar Singh, Government of Bihar; Prof. Stuart Russell, University of California, Berkeley; Suparna Singh, Larsen & Toubro; Susanth Kurunthil, Infoparks Kerala
summary_one_liner: Vertical AI transforming trillion-dollar infrastructure decisions with collective intelligence
icebreaker: Prof. Stuart Russell's here—ask him: how does AI solve construction's biggest sustainability blind spot?
networking_tip: Heavy hitter event with infrastructure CXOs: arrive early, sit with construction tech founders before keynote.

title: Operationalising Open Source AI: Pathways to Sovereignty
description: Context-setting on AI sovereignty, global concentration of AI power and why open source AI are central to equitable and sustainable AI development. This panel positions the discussion within the Summit's broader objectives and India's leadership in digital public infrastructure.
speakers: Calista Redmond, Nvidia; Joelle Pineau, Cohere; Lavu Devaraylu, Parliamentary Chair Telugu Desam Party; Mark Latonero, Responsible AI Future Foundation; Mark Surman, Mozilla; Nikhil Pahwa, Founder of MediaNama
summary_one_liner: Open source AI as the strategic pathway to global AI sovereignty
icebreaker: Mark Surman, how does Mozilla see open-source AI reshaping sovereignty versus the current concentration of AI power?
networking_tip: Tech Foundation Leaders and Policy Makers will converge here. Grab coffee beforehand with DPI Architects to network strategically.

title: The Future is Intelligent: AI in the Cloud-Native Era
description: In order for AI infrsatructure not to be locked into a few vendors, open source cloud native tools could be more widely explored.  This is a first step towards building production AI systems on one's own terms keeping data sovereign, optimising expensive GPUs and serving models more efficiently. This session will explore the use of these tools and include real lessons from industry deployment.
speakers: Bharath N R, Mirantis; Prithvi Raj, Mirantis; Satyam Bhardwaj, Mirantis
summary_one_liner: Open-source cloud-native tools for sovereign, vendor-independent AI deployment
icebreaker: Bharath N R, what's your biggest win with open-source tools avoiding vendor lock-in for production AI systems?
networking_tip: Platform Engineers network post-session at technical booths. Stay for Q&A; they'll cluster there discussing implementation.

title: Genomics, AI, and the Future of Health: Data Visitation to Empower the Global South
description: Realizing global precision medicine requires infrastructure enabling countries to collaborate on AI-driven genomics. Yet data sovereignty rules prevent collective use of genomic datasets, widening the Global AI Divide. Data visitation—where algorithms travel securely to data rather than data moving to researchers—offers a path forward. This workshop convenes policymakers, technologists, and public health leaders to explore governance, standards, and technologies, showcasing how emerging tools translate policy into deployable infrastructure built with the Global South.
speakers: Andrew Soltan, University of Oxford; Binay Panda, Jawaharlal Nehru University; Dawn Chen, Harvard University; Francis Crawley, CODATA International Data Policy Committee; Madhava Jay, OpenMined Foundation; Suchita Ninawe, Department of Biotechnology, GoI; Weibin Liu, Human Genome Project II
summary_one_liner: Data visitation innovation bridging Global South precision medicine access gap
icebreaker: Andrew, how does data visitation solve the data sovereignty paradox you're addressing?
networking_tip: Engage with Oxford, JNU, and Harvard researchers to explore cross-border genomics collaboration opportunities.

title: Startup Spotlight 6: Powering the Next Generation of Autonomous Operations
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Tania
summary_one_liner: Rapid pitch: Next-generation autonomous operations AI startup innovation
icebreaker: Tania, what operational bottleneck does your autonomous platform tackle first?
networking_tip: Arrive early to discuss post-pitch; investors and potential partners often cluster after startup spotlights.

title: Rewriting the Startup Playbook: Not Despite. Because of HER
description: This session will feature a candid conversation on reshaping the startup ecosystem through leadership, resilience, and inclusive innovation. It will also include a rapid pitch by Baeru, an AI-first waste intelligence layer transforming how waste is tracked, managed, and optimized.
speakers:
Rahul Matthan, Partner, Trilegal



; Kanika Tekriwal, CEO, Jet Set Go; Rucha Nanavati, Chief of Advanced Technologies, Farm Equipment Business, M&M Ltd. ; Sarita Ahlawat, MD, Co-Founder, BotLab Dynamics
summary_one_liner: Female-led startup ecosystem reshaping through inclusive innovation and resilience
icebreaker: Kanika or Rucha, how does diversity in leadership reshape AI startup resilience?
networking_tip: Connect with Trilegal partner Rahul for investment structuring conversations post-panel.

title: Startup Spotlight 7: Baeru - an AI-first waste intelligence layer
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Divya Hegde
summary_one_liner: AI-first waste intelligence layer optimizing tracking and management systems
icebreaker: Divya, how does Baeru's AI differentiate waste tracking from existing IoT solutions?
networking_tip: Ask Divya about pilot partnerships; environmental sustainability investors often attend these pitches.

title: AI & Arthik Shakti: A Blueprint for Women led Prosperity
description: The AI & Arthik Shakti session will co-develop an action blueprint for women-led prosperity through AI. The programme will feature keynote addresses and a panel discussion titled "The Prosperity Algorithm: AI's Role in Women's Economic Agency", focusing on inclusive growth, digital empowerment, and measurable pathways to sustainable prosperity across India and the Global South. The session aims to translate dialogue into actionable strategies that strengthen women's economic participation in AI-driven economies.
speakers: Atsuko Okuda, International Telecommunication Union (ITU); Brijesh Singh, Government of Maharashtra; Kartik Shah, Maati Baani; Mihoko Kumamoto, United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR); Vijaya Rahatkar, National Commission for Women (NCW)
knowledge_partners: United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR)
summary_one_liner: Co-creating an AI-powered blueprint for women's economic prosperity
icebreaker: Brijesh Singh, how does your prosperity algorithm center women's economic agency in AI?
networking_tip: UN officials and gender policy makers present—connect during coffee breaks before they network elsewhere.

title: India-Japan AI for the World
description: In the digital field, Japan and India have identified opportunities for cooperation and strengthened engagement. This session will bring together AI companies from both countries for a panel discussion. Participants will gain insights into AI development approaches in Japan and India, as well as potential areas for collaboration in AI development.
speakers: Hirotaro Ohira, Fujitsu Research of India Pvt. Ltd. (FRIPL); Kavita Bhatia, IndiaAI; Lucas Haywood, ONESTRUCTION Inc.; Satish Thiagarajan, TCS Japan; Shiho Nagano, Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI); Shingo Okuma, Highreso; Sunil Gupta, Yotta; Swadeep Singh, IndiaAI; Takumi Miyakawa, Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan
knowledge_partners: Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, Japan
summary_one_liner: India-Japan bilateral AI cooperation unlocks cross-border innovation opportunities
icebreaker: Shingo Okuma, what are Japan's top priorities for India-AI collaboration in the next 18 months?
networking_tip: Japan market entrants should connect with Sunil Gupta and Swadeep Singh during panel breaks for cross-border leads.

title: AI for Fraud Prevention and Financial Inclusion in BFSI
description: This panel explores how, as BFSI systems expand through digital onboarding, payments, and credit, trust can no longer rely on manual oversight or fragmented rule-based controls. It examines AI as a core trust infrastructure—enabling real-time fraud prevention, advanced risk intelligence, and resilient cross-border controls—while ensuring explainability, privacy, auditability, and fairness. The discussion also highlights how AI-driven trust rails reduce friction and unlock financial inclusion at scale for underserved citizens and MSMEs.
speakers: Mr Bhuvan Lodha, Mahindra & Mahindra Limited; Mr Manish Agarwal, Kotak811, Kotak Mahindra Bank; Mr Neeraj Aggarwal, BCG; Mr Saurabh Mittal, DBS India; Mr Srijay Ghosh, Temasek; Mr Suresh Sethi, Protean eGov Technologies; Shri Abhishek Singh, Ministry of Electronics & IT, GoI
summary_one_liner: AI-powered trust infrastructure enabling fraud-free financial inclusion at scale
icebreaker: Saurabh Mittal, how are you rethinking fraud detection for financial inclusion at scale?
networking_tip: BFSI CXOs and fintech founders mix here—position yourself near risk management track conversations.

title: High-level discussion on APAC Centre for AI
description:
This high level Panel Discussion convening at the India AI Impact Summit 2026 will discuss the proposed Asia Pacific Centre for Artificial Intelligence.

The session features a short panel discussion followed by an open audience dialogue to gather practical inputs on cross border collaboration, market expansion, adoption pathways, and governance priorities that can enable innovation while strengthening trust and accountability across the region.
speakers: Dr. Sivaramakrishnan R Guruvayur, Aaquarians.ai; Mr. Jeremy Fritzhand, Ahmedabad University; Mr. Kamesh Shekar, The Dialogue
knowledge_partners: Plug and Play India Pvt. Ltd
summary_one_liner: Shaping the proposed Asia-Pacific Centre for AI collaboration and governance
icebreaker: Jeremy Fritzhand, what's blocking APAC countries from deeper cross-border AI collaboration today?
networking_tip: Policy leaders and startup directors attend—exchange details after panel, they're deciding next moves.

title: Trust as a Global Imperative: How to Operationalise Safe AI for Al
description: AI systems increasingly shape social, economic, and political life, raising concerns about safety, transparency, and trust. Global efforts recognise that trustworthy AI requires more than technical safeguards; it demands ethical foundations, strong governance, and awareness of societal risks. This session brings together leaders from ethics, government, multilateral institutions, and peace research to examine how Safe and Trusted AI can be operationalised through inclusive, evidence-based approaches that advance responsible, globally aligned AI governance and policy practice.
speakers: Dr Chinmay Pandya, Dev Sanskriti Vishwavidyalaya; Ms Gabriela Ramos, UNESCO; Ms Marine Collins Ragnet, NYU's Peace; Paola Galvez, Globethics
summary_one_liner: Operationalizing safe AI through ethics, governance, and multilateral alignment
icebreaker: With Dr Chinmay Pandya speaking, ask how multilateral cooperation is reshaping AI governance frameworks.
networking_tip: Target government officials early—they leave after sessions. Catch them in pre-panel hallway conversations.

title: Scaling AI for Public Health Impact: Public Private Partnership
description: As artificial intelligence (AI) adoption in health accelerates, its public health impact depends on governance, institutional capacity, and effective public–private sector collaboration. This panel examines how AI is being moved from pilots to scale, highlighting implementation experiences, procurement and integration challenges, and sustainability beyond proof-of-concept. Drawing on public and private sector perspectives, the discussion focuses on enabling procurement, ecosystems and practical pathways for responsible, scalable AI deployment in public health systems.
speakers: Dr Sunil Kumar Barnwal, National Health Authority, GoI; Mr Anurag Yadav, Government of Uttar Pradesh; Mr Kiran Gopal Vaska, National Health Authority, GoI; Mr Sourabh Gaur, Department of Health and Family Welfare, Government of AP; Ms Geetha Manjunath, Niramai; Ms. Punya Salila Srivastava, IAS, Govt. of India; Rajan Khobragade, Health & Family Welfare Department, Government of Kerala
knowledge_partners: Indian Council of Medical Research-National Institute for Research in Digital Health and Data Science (ICMR – NIRDHDS)
summary_one_liner: Scaling AI in public health through governance and partnerships
icebreaker: Ms Punya Salila Srivastava IAS, what's your procurement framework for scaling public health AI?
networking_tip: Government officials decide budgets—engage during formal Q&A and break time before they leave early.

title: Building AI for Bharat: From Innovation to Outcomes
description: The future of AI must consider how well it serves those furthest from the digital frontier. With vast linguistic, cultural, and geographic diversity, solutions must be designed for real-world complexity. This panel brings together diverse ecosystem actors to share lessons on moving from innovation to outcomes—mobilising philanthropy, government, and mission-driven organisations to de-risk deployment, build infrastructure, shape standards, and chart a practical roadmap for inclusive, human-centred AI in Bharat.
speakers: Arghya Bhattacharya, Adalat AI; James Walsh, The Agency Fund; Krisha Mathur, ACT Capital Foundation For Social Impact; Prashanth Prakash, Board Member, ACT; Rama Devi Lanka, Frontier Technologies - Niti Aayog; Sandeep Singhal, Board Member, ACT
knowledge_partners: ACT Capital Foundation For Social Impact
summary_one_liner: Mobilizing philanthropy and government to de-risk inclusive AI for Bharat
icebreaker: Prashanth Prakash, which vernacular AI problems are impact investors missing right now?
networking_tip: Impact investors and philanthropic leaders cluster together—join their table during networking breaks.

title: Safe AI Solutions in Education - A Practitioner-oriented Dialogue for the Global South Perspective
description: AI's rapid adoption in education offers remarkable opportunities alongside complex challenges. Adaptive learning tools and automated assessments are transforming student learning and teaching methods. Yet, heavy reliance on these technologies sparks concerns over data protection, bias, accountability, and their long-term effects on learning ecosystems. As India pushes digital education initiatives, responsible design, deployment, and governance of AI systems are essential.
speakers: Anil Ananthaswamy, IIT Madras; Krishnan Narayanan, itihaasa Research & Digital; Shaveta Sharma-Kukreja, Central Square Foundation; Srinivasan Parthasarathy, The Ohio State University; Sunil Wadhwani, Wadhwani AI; Swati Vasudevan, Khan Academy India
knowledge_partners: Centre for Responsible AI (CeRAI), IIT Madras
summary_one_liner: Responsible AI design for education in Global South contexts
icebreaker: Sunil Wadhwani, how do you balance adaptive learning benefits with data protection in Global South schools?
networking_tip: Edtech founders cluster here. Exchange contacts during the Global South education case study discussions.

title: Impact of AI on Tech-Enabled Services: Redefining India's Next Growth Engine
description: India's tech-enabled services sector—spanning IT, BPO, and global capability centres (GCCs)—plays a significant role in economic activity and employment. AI is reshaping this industry by influencing service economics, delivery models, and talent structures. As AI systems advance towards greater autonomy, this session will explore how India can navigate this transition to support higher-value job creation and strengthen its position in the global services economy.
speakers: Akshay Khanna, Avasant; Chandrika Dutt, Avasant; Jagdish Mitra, Humanizetech.ai; Som Chatterjee, Prsimforce; Swapnil Bhatnagar, Avasant
summary_one_liner: AI reshapes India's IT/BPO services toward higher-value job creation
icebreaker: Akshay Khanna, how are IT services leaders preparing their GCCs for AI-driven workforce shifts?
networking_tip: IT services executives and BPO leaders gather here—they're actively hiring and evaluating AI tools now.

title: Building Safe and Trusted AI Through Fair and Transparent AI Supply Chain Labour
description: This session explores AI's hidden labour challenge, framing standards as governance tools for a planetary AI labour market. It examines cross-border data work, gaps in existing labour frameworks, and how standards and certification shape accountability across AI supply chains. With a Fairwork presentation and expert panel, it evaluates what standards can govern, their influence on firms and policy, and when they become effective instruments for meaningful labour protection and equitable outcomes for workers worldwide today.
speakers: Balaji Parthasarathy, International Institute of Information Technology; Dr. Patrick Feuerstein, Social Science Research Center Berlin; Mark Graham, Oxford Internet Institute; Sarayu Natarajan, Aapti Institute
knowledge_partners:
Fairwork,
Oxford Internet Institute, University of Oxford
summary_one_liner: Governance standards for AI's hidden global data labor supply chain
icebreaker: Mark Graham's research on data workers fascinates me—what labor standards do you think should apply globally?
networking_tip: Smaller audience on ethics means easier access to speakers. Arrive early to claim a seat near the panelists.

title: AI and Media: Opportunities, Responsible Pathways, and the Road Ahead
description: This panel convenes senior leaders from the media and publishing ecosystem, global experts, and representatives from leading international consulting firms to examine how AI is reshaping the future of news. Designed as a leadership-level discussion, it will explore responsible AI integration across editorial, business, and operations, highlighting opportunities for innovation, efficiency, and audience engagement. The session will also address evolving economic models, trust, transparency, safety, and long-term sustainability, offering strategic clarity and actionable insights.
speakers: Ashish Pherwani, Ernst & Young LLP; Kalli Purie, India Today Group; Mohit Jain, Bennett, Coleman & Co Ltd; Navaneeth LV, The Hindu Group; Pawan Agarwal, Dainik Bhaskar Group; Robert Whitehead, International News Media Association; Tanmay Maheshwari, Amar Ujala Publications
summary_one_liner: AI transforms news media with responsible editorial innovation strategies
icebreaker: Ashish, how is your organization planning to adapt editorial workflows as AI reshapes content production?
networking_tip: Target media executives during breaks—they control budgets for AI tools. Ask about their biggest content trust challenges.

title: National Launch Event: AI Readiness Assessment Methodology (RAM) Report of India
description: The India AI Readiness Assessment Methodology (RAM) Report will be launched at the AI Impact Summit on 16 February, from 3:30–4:25 PM in Room 15, Bharat Mandapam. Developed by UNESCO in partnership with the IndiaAI Mission and implemented by Ikigai Law, the report examines India's current ethical AI landscape and preparedness, and offers actionable recommendations. The event will feature a keynote by Dr. Ajay Kumar Sood, Principal Scientific Advisor to the Government of India.
speakers: Dr Ajay Kumar Sood, IISc; Dr Mariagrazia Squicciarini, UNESCO; Mr. Abhishek Singh, Ministry of Electronics & IT, GoI; Mr. S. Krishnan, Ministry of Electronics & IT, GoI; Mr. Tim Curtis, UNESCO; Ms. Eunsong Kim, UNESCO
summary_one_liner: UNESCO launches India's AI readiness assessment with actionable policy recommendations
icebreaker: Dr. Ajay Kumar Sood—how will India's RAM report influence policy decisions for AI governance?
networking_tip: High-density policy makers present. Position yourself near UNESCO officials and Indian government representatives.

title: The Future of Work for the Global South: Skilling for Opportunity and Social Mobility
description: This high-level panel explores how AI-driven workforce transformation can unlock economic opportunities and social mobility across the Global South. Convening policymakers, industry leaders, and practitioners, the session examines critical skills gaps, regional priorities, and actionable frameworks for inclusive AI upskilling. Drawing on India's policy leadership and cross-country insights, participants will engage in dialogue to shape future-proof roadmaps that ensure equitable access to AI skills, empowering vulnerable populations and strengthening workforce readiness across emerging economies.
speakers: Abhineet Kaul, Access Partnerships; Abhishek Singh, IndiaAI Mission and Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY); Angelica Salvi Del Pero, OECD (France); Anjali Kaur, Chair on India and Emerging Asia Economics, Center for Strategic and International Studies; Chenie Yoon, Google; Naina Subberwal Batra, AVPN
summary_one_liner: AI-driven upskilling roadmaps unlocking social mobility across emerging economies
icebreaker: Anjali Kaur, what's the biggest skilling gap AI could actually solve in the Global South?
networking_tip: CHROs and workforce leaders are decision-makers—catch them post-panel when less busy than during sessions.

title: Demo: National Data Analytics Platform – Unlocking Public Data for Innovation
description: This session will feature a live demonstration of the National Data Analytics Platform, showcasing how public data can be leveraged to drive research, policymaking, and innovation. It will also include a rapid pitch spotlighting an exceptional AI startup selected for its innovation and impact.
speakers: Megha Pandey, Senior Business Analyst, OTSi
summary_one_liner: Live demo: Public data analytics unlocking research, policy, and innovation potential
icebreaker: Megha, which public dataset has unlocked the most unexpected innovation use cases?
networking_tip: Request a 1-on-1 with OTSi to discuss API access and dataset integration strategies.

title: Demo: National Data Analytics Platform – Unlocking Public Data for Innovation
description: This session will feature a live demonstration of the National Data Analytics Platform, showcasing how public data can be leveraged to drive research, policymaking, and innovation. It will also include a rapid pitch spotlighting an exceptional AI startup selected for its innovation and impact.
speakers: Megha Pandey, Senior Business Analyst, OTSi
summary_one_liner: Live demo: Public data analytics unlocking research, policy, and innovation potential
icebreaker: Megha, what's the biggest barrier to scaling public data adoption across sectors?
networking_tip: Meet policy leaders here to understand data availability roadmaps and compliance requirements.

title: Startup Spotlight 8: Arghyam
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Manu Srivastava
summary_one_liner: Rapid pitch: Exceptional AI startup innovating social or environmental impact
icebreaker: Manu, what water-related challenge does Arghyam solve that existing solutions miss?
networking_tip: Impact investors and sustainability-focused VCs cluster after social-impact startup pitches.

title: Expert Speaks: Going Global - Guidance on Leadership
speakers: Dr Sarika Aggarwal
summary_one_liner: Global expansion strategies for emerging tech leaders
icebreaker: Dr Aggarwal, what's the biggest cultural shift you advise founders on when scaling internationally?
networking_tip: Ask about market-entry strategies in specific geographies—founders scaling regionally always share battle-tested frameworks.

title: Startup Spotlight 9: The World's First AI Platform for K-12 Entrepreneurship
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Rajani Nalla
summary_one_liner: AI platform democratizing entrepreneurship education for K-12
icebreaker: Rajani, how does AI make entrepreneurship accessible to students who've never coded before?
networking_tip: Connect with education investors and K-12 tech buyers—they're actively seeking solutions in this space.

title: Building Things to Transform – Breaking the Mould (Innovation beyond the routine)
description: This session will feature a forward-looking discussion on building transformative technologies that challenge conventional models and unlock frontier innovation. It will spotlight bold approaches across healthtech and AI, highlighting how mission-driven ventures are reshaping industries beyond routine thinking.
speakers:
Debjani Ghosh, Distinguished Fellow & Chief Architect, Frontier Tech Hub Initiative, NITI Aayog 



; Dr Sunita Maheshwari, Chief Dreamer, The Telerad Group


; Vidur Mahajan, Founder & CEO, CARPL.ai; Nagendra Nagaraja, CEO, QpiAI; Pratyush Kumar, Co-founder, Sarvam AI
summary_one_liner: Frontier tech ventures reimagining healthcare and AI innovation
icebreaker: Debjani, what distinguishes frontier healthtech from incremental improvements in NITI's evaluation?
networking_tip: NITI Aayog officials and mission-driven founders here—ideal for government partnerships and policy-aware scale strategies.

title: Building Trust: Digital Infrastructure Fit for the AI Era
description: AI is reshaping how sovereignty is understood for individuals, communities, and nations. While governments played a major role in building the early internet, private actors have also shaped the digital economy. Today, AI development is largely led by the private sector, raising questions about how to align innovation with broader societal goals. This panel will explore how to build trustworthy infrastructure through public-private alignment and governance approaches that prioritize users and accountability. Key takeaways will be distilled across international policy platforms.
speakers: Dr. Arvind Gupta, Digital India Foundation; Dr. Tomicah Tillemann, Project Liberty Institute; Robert Opp, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP); Sarah Nicole, Project Liberty Institute; Supheakmungkol Sarin, AI Safety Asia; Vidisha Mishra, Global Solutions Initiative
summary_one_liner: Trustworthy digital infrastructure through public-private governance alignment
icebreaker: Dr. Arvind Gupta on AI sovereignty—how are you rethinking digital trust for your organization?
networking_tip: Policy leaders and GovCIOs will congregate during panel. Approach with a specific sovereignty question.

title: AI as an Opportunity for More Impactful Open Data
description: This session explores how AI can strengthen open public data systems to deliver greater social and economic value. The session explores the policy, institutional, and technical conditions needed for AI-ready data ecosystems, highlighting the role of National Statistical Offices, transparency, and collaboration in building trust, while simultaneously improving data quality.
speakers: Christopher Maloney, Gender Equity and Governance Program, William and Flora Hewlett Foundation; François Fonteneau, PARIS 21; Mercedes Fogarassy, PARIS 21; Randeep Toor, Google; Rohit Bhardwaj, National Statistical Office, India
summary_one_liner: AI strengthens open data systems for greater social and economic value
icebreaker: François Fonteneau from OECD—what conditions make open data truly AI-ready for government agencies?
networking_tip: National statistics officials here seeking data infrastructure advice. Lead with your organization's open data maturity.

title: Global Mission on AI for Energy Scaling through citizen-centric India Energy Stack
description: The world is entering a decisive decade for energy transition, with rapid solar growth and complex grids driving the need for AI-enabled digitalisation. India's experience, including the India Energy Stack, shows how scalable, inclusive digital public infrastructure can move from pilots to impact. Building on this the Ministry of Power, REC Ltd. and ISA are convening this session to advance a Global Mission on AI for Energy through collaboration and citizen-centric power systems.
speakers: Mr. Abhishek Ranjan, BRPL; Mr. Ashish Khanna, ISA; Mr. Jeremy Oppenheim, SystemIQ; Mr. Prince Dhawan, REC Limited; Mr.Karan Mangotra, International Solar Alliance; Ms. Arti Dogra IAS, JVVNL; Ms. Swetha Ravi Kumar, FSR Global; Sri Pankaj Agarwal, GoI
summary_one_liner: India Energy Stack powers global AI-driven clean energy mission
icebreaker: Jeremy Oppenheim, how does India's Energy Stack model apply to other energy transition markets?
networking_tip: Energy executives and climate tech founders heavily represented. Pitch DPI solutions during energy transition discussions.

title: Advancing AI Safety Across Languages, Cultures and Contexts
description: This panel discussion will explore why multilingual safety is essential for inclusive AI governance, addressing emerging risks such as jailbreaking in low-resource languages, and the current lack of culturally grounded benchmarks and evaluation frameworks. Participants will examine the challenges of building culturally sensitive safety datasets and ensuring that AI models can be developed, evaluated, and deployed safely across diverse linguistic and socio-cultural contexts, and highlight opportunities for collaborative research and open evaluation infrastructure.
speakers: Fabrice Ciais, G42; Marzieh Fadaee, Cohere; Natasha Crampton, Microsoft; Nicolas Miailhe, PrismEval; Nitarshan Rajkumar, Anthropic; Peter Mattson, MLCommons; Sara Hooker, Adaptable Intelligence; Sunayana Sitaram, Microsoft Research; Wan Sie Lee, Singapore AISI; Wassim Hamidouche, Microsoft
summary_one_liner: Multilingual AI safety benchmarks essential for inclusive global governance
icebreaker: Sara Hooker and Sunayana Sitaram's work on jailbreaking in low-resource languages—seen that risk in your deployment?
networking_tip: NLP researchers cluster in technical tracks. Wait for Q&A to spot your strongest peer connections.

title: Building High-Quality AI Systems for Education: From Innovation to System-Wide Delivery
description: This session examines how countries can design and scale high-quality, context-appropriate AI tools for education. It highlights key risks and opportunities, with use cases from Africa and India, and discusses quality assurance across the AI lifecycle. The panellists will share lessons from testing and deploying AI in classrooms and public services, and present insights on integrating AI into government systems, conditions required to scale AI safely and coherently.
speakers: Jairaj Bhattacharya, ConveGenius; Jonathan Stern, Gates Foundation; Kalpana Sharma, Lakshmibai National Institute of Physical Education; Marc Shotland, IDinsight; Paul Atherton, Fab AI; Romana Kropilova, Fab AI
summary_one_liner: Scaling context-appropriate AI education tools from Africa to India
icebreaker: Marc Shotland, which Africa-India use cases show the most promise for system-wide edtech scale?
networking_tip: Education ministry officials attend—focus on how AI improves learning outcomes, not just tech specs.

title: Preparing National Research Ecosystems for AI: Strategies and Progress
description: Artificial intelligence is transforming how science is conducted, governed, and funded, outpacing many national research systems. Marking the launch of the International Science Council's report Preparing National Research Ecosystems for AI, this session draws on 26 country case studies, especially from low- and middle-income contexts. Panelists will examine governance, data and compute access, workforce skills, and policy alignment, highlighting shared challenges, good practices, and the need for international cooperation to ensure AI advances science equitably.
speakers: Felix Dijkstal, International Science Council; Jibu Elias, Mozilla Foundation, Co-creator, INIDAai; Moses M Thiga, Egerton University, Kenya; Vanessa McBride, International Science Council
summary_one_liner: 26-country study reveals how nations can prepare research for AI
icebreaker: The ISC report launch—Felix Dijkstal flagged compute access gaps. What's blocking your research ecosystem?
networking_tip: Science policy advisors attend regularly. Hit the coffee area right after the ISC report reveal.

title: Unlocking Impact: a Shared Data Platform for AI Innovation in Development Cooperation
description: This workshop will introduce a data and AI platform for cooperation and discuss its vision and early applications. It will examine how governments, implementing agencies, and innovators can collaborate to use AI in combination with data and contextual insights. Participants will explore the need for interoperable and trusted infrastructure to support AI agents, and consider how such systems can strengthen the effectiveness of development-related initiatives.
speakers: Dr. Iliya Peter Nickelt-Czycykowski, German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development, BMZ; Gaurav Godhwani, CivicDataLab; Karolin Erdman, GIZ GmbH (German Agency for International Cooperation); Navya Alam, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)
knowledge_partners: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)
summary_one_liner: Shared data platform enables AI innovation in development cooperation
icebreaker: Gaurav Godhwani's data platform for development—how could your organization tap interoperable infrastructure?
networking_tip: Workshop format = deep dives. Sit near GovTech innovators; workshop breaks spark best conversations.

title: AI for ESG: Responsible Innovation for People, Planet and Progress
description: AI's growing role in economies and institutions makes its alignment with ESG priorities critical. While AI can strengthen climate monitoring, risk management, governance, transparency, and accountability, poorly governed use may amplify bias, inequality, and mistrust. This panel frames AI as a leadership and governance challenge, not just a technology, examining responsible, ethical, and policy-aligned deployment. It explores how AI can deliver inclusive, transparent, measurable ESG outcomes, especially for emerging economies and the Global South contexts.
speakers: Dr. Manuj Bhardwaj, Dhirubhai Ambani University – School of Law; Ms. Ayisha Piotti, RegHorizon; Ms. Maya Sherman, Embassy of Israel in India; Ms. Sarith Felber, Ministry of Justice, Israel; Prof Victor Alchanatis, Volcani Institute, Israel; Prof. (Dr.) Avinash Dadhich, Dhirubhai Ambani University
knowledge_partners: Dhirubhai Ambani University School of Law
summary_one_liner: Responsible AI deployment delivers measurable ESG outcomes for Global South
icebreaker: Ask Prof. Avinash Dadhich how ESG frameworks should evolve for emerging AI risks.
networking_tip: Seek ESG-focused investors—they fund responsible innovation with patient capital.

title: Women, Work, and the Future of AI
description: This session blends film, dialogue, and live demonstration to explore who shapes AI and on whose terms. Featuring a screening of 'Humans in the Loop', a moderated panel aligned with the India AI Impact Summit's chakra framework, and a demo of a Gender Bias Benchmarking tool, the session centers women's inclusion, data workers' visibility, local context, and dignified digital work as pillars of responsible AI.
speakers: Aranya Sahay, Humans in the Loop; Arjun Venkatraman, Gates Foundation; Dr. Kalika Bali, Microsoft Research India; Dr. Shikoh Gitau, Qhala Limited; Safiya Husain, Karya; Urvashi Aneja, Digital Futures Lab
summary_one_liner: Centering women's inclusion and data workers' dignity in AI systems
icebreaker: After 'Humans in the Loop'—Dr. Kalika Bali's work on data workers just hit different. What's your experience?
networking_tip: DEI officers and social impact folks will linger post-screening. Grab them during the film discussion debrief.

title: Publicly Accessible Data and AI Training: Safeguards for Responsible Reuse
description: This session explores how data governance shapes ethical, transparent, and rights-respecting AI systems used by governments and private actors. It shares early findings from a research project examining the legal and ethical use of publicly accessible data in AI training, with insights from multiple global contexts. Through interactive discussion, the session invites audience perspectives to deepen understanding of emerging challenges and help inform future research directions and policy approaches for responsible, inclusive AI development.
speakers: Fola Adeleke, Global Center on AI Governance; Renato Berrino Malaccorto, Open Data Charter; Vinay Narayan, Aapti; Violeta Belver, ILDA
summary_one_liner: Ethical frameworks for using publicly accessible data in AI training
icebreaker: Vinay Narayan, what safeguards have proven most effective in your data governance research project?
networking_tip: Smaller crowd means one-on-one time with data ethics experts. Ask about their upcoming policy recommendations.

title: The Sustainable Digital Infrastructure Accord Driving Sustainability of AI Infrastructure in the Asia-Pacific Region
description: Aligned with the 'Planet' sutra, this event involves a panel discussion to explore how industry practices for data centres and policy frameworks can advance the sustainability of AI infrastructure in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region. The event will commence with a brief presentation on the Sustainable Digital Infrastructure Accord (SDIA), a unique APAC-level industry initiative to advance digital infrastructure sustainability through voluntary targets covering four areas- energy efficiency, clean energy use, water use, and circular economy.
speakers: Alexander Smith, Google; Bimal Khandelwal, ST Telemedia Global Data Centres; David Skelton, Flint Global
summary_one_liner: APAC data centre sustainability accord sets voluntary green targets
icebreaker: David Skelton, how can data centres in Asia-Pacific align with the Sustainable Digital Infrastructure Accord?
networking_tip: Data centre operators cluster around sustainability discussions. Connect on energy efficiency ROI during break.

title: AI x Creativity: Skilling for Innovation in the Intelligent Economy
description: The session explores a powerful convergence of artificial intelligence and human creativity in shaping the future workforce. This high-impact panel brings together leaders from industry, government, and the creative economy to discuss how AI is transforming design, media, storytelling, and innovation. The session highlights future-ready skills, national skilling pathways, and collaborative initiatives enabling India's intelligent and creative economy.
speakers: Dr Ashish Kulkarni, Punnaryug Artvision; Dr. Abhilasha Gaur, NASSCOM-SSC; Jayadev Gopalakrishnan, Adobe; Mala Sharma, Adobe; Rana Daggubati, Anthill Studio; Rishi Raj Singh, Make My Trip; Saransh Agrawal, Cognizant
summary_one_liner: AI-powered creative skills for next-generation workforce design
icebreaker: Jayadev, how is Adobe thinking about reskilling creators who worry AI replaces their craft?
networking_tip: Adobe, NASSCOM, and MakeMyTrip leaders here—great for understanding enterprise creative AI adoption trends.

title: Frontier Tech Hub Repository
description: This session will feature an overview of the Frontier Tech Hub Repository, highlighting how it curates and connects breakthrough innovations across emerging technologies. It will also include a rapid pitch spotlighting an exceptional AI startup selected for its innovation and impact.
speakers: Sachi Chopra, Program Architect, NITI Frontier Tech Hub
summary_one_liner: NITI's curated innovation repository for breakthrough deep tech
icebreaker: Sachi, what emerging tech categories are you seeing breakthrough innovations in right now?
networking_tip: NITI officials curating India's frontier tech—investors and founders should ask about repository access and support programs.

title: Harnessing AI for Health Equity: Building Inclusive Human Capital and Strengthening Research–Industry Collaboration
description: This high-level panel will explore how AI can strengthen global health while keeping inclusion and social equity central. The conversation will focus on building human capital for AI-driven health innovation, catalyzing inclusive participation, and strengthening research–industry linkages so scientific insights translate into practical health solutions. The aim is to identify clear priorities, collaboration pathways, and measurable actions that support responsible AI adoption and a more equitable digital health future.
speakers: Dr. Mona Duggal, ICMR; Mr Abhimanyu Saxena, UNDP India; Ms. Nande Putta, UNICEF; Ms. Vinita Sethi, Independent Director; Prof (Dr.) Balvir S Tomar, NIMS University Rajasthan, Jaipur; Prof. Dr Anurag Agrawal:, Ashoka University; Prof. Dr Sanjay Pattanshetty, NIMS University, Rajasthan, Jaipur; Prof. Ilona Kickbusch, Global Health Centre at the Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies, Geneva
summary_one_liner: Building inclusive human capital for AI-driven global health innovation
icebreaker: Prof. Ilona Kickbusch, how do med schools build AI literacy without overwhelming faculty?
networking_tip: Medical education leaders are rare—connect with deans during lunch to discuss research partnership opportunities.

title: From Guidelines to Ground: Institutional AI Safety for India and the Global South
description: This roundtable convenes government, industry, legal, and diplomatic leaders to translate responsible AI principles into enforceable institutional guardrails for India and the Global South. Participants will examine real-world deployment failures, identify binding constraints in enforcement, audit bandwidth, and procurement, and develop minimum viable safeguards for high-adoption, low-capacity settings. Outputs include an Institutional Safety Case Standard and Red Teaming Checklist. The session bridges policy intent with ground-level implementation realities.
speakers: Abdullah, Zephara AI; Arundhati Banerjee, Nvidia; Dr. Arjun Goswami, Cyril Amarchand Mangaldas; Jameela Sahiba, The Dialogue; Juan Carlos Rojas Arango, Embassy of Colombia; Kamesh Shekar, The Dialogue; Prof. Sidharth Chauhan, The Cyril Shroff Centre for AI Law and Regulation (JGU); Ravi Aurora, Mastercard; Sidharth Deb, The Quantum Hub; Udit Malik, Government of France
summary_one_liner: Translating responsible AI principles into enforceable institutional guardrails
icebreaker: Ask Arundhati Banerjee how Nvidia sees institutional guardrails enabling rather than blocking innovation.
networking_tip: Exchange contacts with diplomats—they bridge global AI governance gaps.

title: Data Sharing Infrastructures for AI: Building for Trust, Purpose, and Public Values
description: This panel discussion is part of the India-AI Impact Summit 2026 which seeks to highlight the demonstrable impact and tangible progress in global AI cooperation. The objective of the panel is to create common principles and guidance for data as DPI that support openness, accountability, and public value in the age of AI, and work towards concrete impact.
speakers: Astha Kapoor, Aapti Institute; Chenai Chair, Masakhane Language Hub; Rahul Matthan, Trilegal; Saranya Gopinath, RazorPay; Vijay Suresh Kumar, Gates Foundation
summary_one_liner: Common principles for data-as-DPI supporting openness and public value
icebreaker: Rahul Matthan's data sharing framework—how do startups balance open data with IP protection?
networking_tip: DPI architects + policy researchers = dual audience. Lead with public value impact, not just tech innovation.

title: Generation AI @ 2047
description: Generation AI @ 2047 is a high-impact, experience-led session aligned with India's focus on inclusive and scalable AI. Moving beyond policy intent, it explores how AI shows up at India's last mile - shaping outcomes for farmers, classrooms, and first-time job seekers. Hosted in Hindi, it spotlights a state-level AI skilling initiative, offering practical, replicable insights for building an inclusive, AI-ready workforce toward a Viksit Bharat by 2047.
speakers: Mr. ⁠Kishore Balaji, IBM; Mr. Lokesh Mehra, Amazon Web Services; Mr. Manav Subodh, 1M1B; ⁠Ms. Neha Jain, IAS, UP DESCO; Ms. Shipra Sharma, IBM
summary_one_liner: Hindi-first AI skilling reaches India's farmers, classrooms, and job seekers
icebreaker: Ms. Neha Jain, IAS—what's blocking Hindi AI adoption at state level and how can vendors help?
networking_tip: State officials + skilling leaders = procurement-focused crowd. Demo last-mile use cases, not enterprise features.

title: Towards Global Cooperation for Equitable AI in Healthcare
description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) promises to transform healthcare delivery worldwide, improving diagnostics, access, and system efficiency. Yet biased datasets, exclusionary design choices, and uneven deployment risk reinforcing inequities and disproportionately harming already marginalised communities, including the elderly, persons with disabilities, and rural populations. This interdisciplinary panel will explore inclusive AI strategies, such as participatory design, representative data practices, and context-sensitive governance frameworks, to ensure that AI systems in healthcare are designed, developed, and deployed in ways that mitigate unintended harm. The focus is on building equitable digital health ecosystems that proactively address structural disparities rather than amplify them.
speakers: Dr. Krithika Rangaranjan, AIIMS, New Delhi; Dr. Mahima Kalla, Centre for Digital Transformation of Health, University of Melbourne; Dr. Mahima Kalla, Centre for Digital Transformation of Health, University of Melbourne; Mr. Aman Taneja, Ikigai Law; Mr. Aman Taneja, Ikigai Law; Mr. Mohit Jain, Microsoft India; Ms. Kanika Kalra, World Health Organization; Ms. Tess Buckley, techUK
knowledge_partners: Centre for Digital Transformation of Health (CDTH), The University of Melbourne
summary_one_liner: Inclusive AI strategies bridge health inequities for marginalized communities
icebreaker: Dr. Krithika Rangaranjan, which marginalized communities should HealthTech founders prioritize first?
networking_tip: Smaller crowd = easier access to speakers. Grab Dr. Krithika early for 1-on-1 conversation before panels get busy.

title: Reimagining Accessibility of Public Broadcasting Data in the AI Era: Creating Virtuous Production of Data for Local Language LLMs
description: This session will gather policymakers and AI practitioners from India and Africa to discuss accessibility of public data, local language LLM training and development requirements, and sustainable financing. The goal is to recommend a governance framework for making public broadcasting data available for public AI research securely. The discussion will focus on regulatory frameworks, practical data use for local language AI, and sustainable funding.
speakers: Alison Gillwald, Research ICT Africa; Diana Mosquera, Diversa Studio; Gaurav Godhiwani, CivicDataLab; Geetha Raju, CeRAI - IIT Madras; Manu Chopra, Karya; Medhi Snene, UN Office for Digital and Emerging Technologies; Mukelani Dimba, Information Regulator of South Africa; Pria Chetty, Research ICT Africa; Siphokazi Novukuza, South African Department of Communications and Digital Technologies; Souhila Amazouz, African Union Commission; Tajuddeen Gwadabe, Masakhane African Languages Hub
summary_one_liner: Public broadcasting data governance enables local language LLM development
icebreaker: Geetha Raju and Alison Gillwald on local language LLMs—what's your language gap in AI right now?
networking_tip: Africa-India NLP researchers will cross-pollinate. Introduce yourself in the data governance track sessions.

title: Agri AI: Advancing Responsible AI for Agriculture
description: This session brings together leading stakeholders from governments, civil society and academia to advance responsible AI for agriculture. The session features inaugural addresses, keynote insights and cross-border panels on scaling AI for public good. With participation from policymakers, researchers, investors and innovators, the program highlights international collaboration, startup recognition and actionable dialogue to strengthen inclusive, impact-driven AI ecosystems for sustainable agricultural development.
speakers: Dr Mukesh Kestwal, IIT Ropar – Technology & Innovation Foundation; Dr. Gal Zohar, Israeli Public Employment Service; Dr. Pushpendra P. Singh, ANNAM.AI and iHub - AWaDH; Dr. Radhika Trikha, IIT Ropar – Technology & Innovation Foundation; Mr. Mayuresh Raut, Seafund; Ms. Maya Serman, Embassy of Israel in India; Ms. Nemesisa Ujjain, The Circle FC; Ms. Sarit Felber, Israeli Ministry of Justice; Ms. Urmi Tat, Salesforce; Prof. Dov Greenbaum, Zvi Meitar Institute; Prof. Victor Alchanatis, Institute of Agricultural and Biosystems Engineering
knowledge_partners: IIT Ropar - Technology and Innovation Foundation
summary_one_liner: Cross-border collaboration scales responsible AI for sustainable agriculture
icebreaker: Dr. Mukesh Kestwal, what's the biggest misconception about AI in farming you've encountered?
networking_tip: Find AgriTech founders during breaks—they're your ideal collaborators for scaling responsible AI pilots.

title: Startup Spotlight 10: Sychedelic: Headphones beyond music
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Ria Rustagi
summary_one_liner: Next-gen wearable audio with AI-driven health and wellness
icebreaker: Ria, what health insights does your headphone platform capture that traditional wearables miss?
networking_tip: Early-stage biotech and health-focused investors likely here—pitch the clinical validation roadmap if you get a chance.

title: Startup Spotlight 10: Sychedelic: Headphones beyond music
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Ria Rustagi
summary_one_liner: Next-gen wearable audio with AI-driven health and wellness
icebreaker: Ria, what health insights does your headphone platform capture that traditional wearables miss?
networking_tip: Early-stage biotech and health-focused investors likely here—pitch the clinical validation roadmap if you get a chance.

title: Harnessing AI for Health Equity: Building Inclusive Human Capital and Strengthening Research–Industry Collaboration
description: This high-level panel will explore how AI can strengthen global health while keeping inclusion and social equity central. The conversation will focus on building human capital for AI-driven health innovation, catalyzing inclusive participation, and strengthening research–industry linkages so scientific insights translate into practical health solutions. The aim is to identify clear priorities, collaboration pathways, and measurable actions that support responsible AI adoption and a more equitable digital health future.
speakers: Dr. Mona Duggal, ICMR; Mr Abhimanyu Saxena, UNDP India; Ms. Nande Putta, UNICEF; Ms. Vinita Sethi, Independent Director; Prof (Dr.) Balvir S Tomar, NIMS University Rajasthan, Jaipur; Prof. Dr Anurag Agrawal:, Ashoka University; Prof. Dr Sanjay Pattanshetty, NIMS University, Rajasthan, Jaipur; Prof. Ilona Kickbusch, Global Health Centre at the Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies, Geneva
summary_one_liner: AI-driven health equity through inclusive research and industry partnerships
icebreaker: Dr. Duggal, how is ICMR thinking about inclusive participation in AI-driven health research across India?
networking_tip: ICMR, UNDP, and UNICEF officials here—explore research collaboration and health equity funding opportunities directly.

title: AI for Power – Accelerating the Clean Energy Transition
description: AI for Power – Accelerating the Clean Energy Transition explores how artificial intelligence can fast-track India's shift to resilient, low-carbon electricity systems. With power driving most global emissions, the session spotlights frontier pilots and scalable innovations across renewable integration, grid optimisation, predictive maintenance and demand forecasting. Policymakers, utilities, innovators and investors will examine pathways to deploy responsible AI at scale - positioning India and the Global South as leaders in climate-positive digital infrastructure.
speakers: Abhishek Ranjan; Mahesh Patankar; Nalin Agarwal; Namrata Mukherjee; Siddharth Singh; Sujith Nair
summary_one_liner: AI accelerates India's clean energy grid with scalable innovations
icebreaker: Sujith Nair's grid optimization work—how's AI changing your clean energy investment thesis?
networking_tip: Climate tech founders and energy execs both attend. Position yourself near the renewable energy sector cluster.

title: Building Resilient, Sustainable AI Infrastructure for People, Planet and Progress
description: AI at scale requires infrastructure that converts promise into real impact. This session explores shared compute, efficient architectures, and hybrid cloud-to-edge strategies, comparing frontier model training with deployment of right-sized models for citizens, SMEs, and public systems. Anchored in People, Planet, and Progress, we examine access, affordability, sustainability, and optimization in India as core design constraints. The discussion addresses what should be built nationally, what collaboration can unlock, and where geopolitical frictions may arise globally.
speakers: Ashish Aggarwal; Nicole Foster; Rishi Bal; Ritu Mehrotra; Sharad Agarwal; Vrushali Gaud
summary_one_liner: Designing affordable, sustainable AI compute infrastructure for India's citizens
icebreaker: Sharad Agarwal's hybrid cloud approach—how does it cut costs vs. pure cloud for frontier models?
networking_tip: Cloud architects cluster naturally—position yourself near the infrastructure breakout to spot hiring needs early.

title: AI Horizons: Building Safe and Trusted AI
description: The session will examine key issues around AI safety, governance, ethics, and international collaboration. It aims to bring together regulators and leading technology organisations to share policy insights, best practices, and perspectives on the development of trustworthy and secure AI deployment. The session aims to encourage informed dialogue, strengthen responsible innovation frameworks, and advance global cooperation to build safe, transparent, and trusted AI ecosystems.
speakers: David Wroe; Dr M M Oberoi; Dr Sanjay Bahl; Kanishk Gaur; Natasha Crampton
summary_one_liner: Regulators and tech leaders align on trustworthy AI deployment frameworks
icebreaker: Dr. Sanjay Bahl's take: which AI safety capability should tech teams hire for first?
networking_tip: High decision-maker density + regulation focus = perfect for recruiting compliance and safety engineering talent.

title: Early Sparks, Big Impact: The Next Generation of Innovators
description: This session will feature emerging innovators showcasing early-stage ideas with the potential for significant real-world impact. It will also include a rapid pitch spotlighting an exceptional AI startup selected for its innovation and transformative promise.
speakers: Chintan Vaishnav, Researcher, MIT
summary_one_liner: Early-stage AI innovators pitching real-world impact solutions
icebreaker: Ask Chintan Vaishnav about which emerging innovation excites him most this year.
networking_tip: Connect with founders during pitch breaks—they're most receptive post-presentation.

title: Large Cultural Models - Building ethical and cultural AI from India, for the world
description: Eros Innovation will unveil India’s First Large Cultural Models (LCMs) and a sovereign AI Creator Economy platform powered by Ethical and Cultural AI. The session will demonstrate how culturally intelligent AI can enable inclusive, citizen-scale creative and economic participation across India.
speakers: Kishore Lulla; Ridhima Lulla; Vikram Tanna; Piyush Bhatia
summary_one_liner: India's first Large Cultural Models democratizing creative AI economy
icebreaker: Ask Kishore Lulla how culturally-intelligent AI differs from western foundation models.
networking_tip: Demo attendees often linger—position yourself near tech showcases for deep convos.

title: Startup Spotlight 11: Aquaairx Autonomous Systems Private Limited
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Gouthami T S
summary_one_liner: Aquaairx autonomous systems rapid pitch for water/environmental impact
icebreaker: Ask Gouthami T S what water challenge Aquaairx solves with autonomy.
networking_tip: Approach founders immediately after pitches when energy is highest.

title: Startup Spotlight 12: RoshniAI by Dharmalife
description: A rapid pitch by an exceptional AI startup, selected for its innovation and impact
speakers: Gaurav Mehta
summary_one_liner: RoshniAI by Dharmalife rapid pitch for healthcare/social impact AI
icebreaker: Ask Gaurav Mehta what health problem RoshniAI addresses with AI.
networking_tip: Have a specific question about their solution ready—founders appreciate engaged listeners.

title: From Access to Acceleration: How WEP Supports Women Founders
description: This session will feature insights into how the Women Entrepreneurship Platform (WEP) enables access, mentorship, funding, and market linkages to accelerate women-led ventures. It will also include the announcement of the top 10 teams, recognizing high-potential founders driving innovation and impact.
speakers: Anna Roy, Mission Director, WEP
summary_one_liner: Women Entrepreneurship Platform accelerating founder funding and market access
icebreaker: Ask Anna Roy what's the #1 blocker she sees for women-led startups.
networking_tip: Top 10 winners will be announced—network with them directly for partnerships.

title: Tata AI Sakhi Immersion Program
description:
What happens when 1,600 rural women pick up their smartphones and try AI for the first time
in Hindi? This hands-on session brings together artisans, entrepreneurs, and community leaders from six
states to experience how AI can help them in their daily work and livelihoods. With guided support from
mentors, participants will use AI to explore new product designs, create marketing materials, navigate
government schemes, translate documents, and draft applications — all on their own phones, in their
own language. No prior tech experience needed.
speakers: Srividhya Muralidharan, Tata Consultancy Services
summary_one_liner: 1,600 rural women experience AI hands-on for the first time
icebreaker: Srividhya, what surprised you most about rural women's first AI interaction in Hindi?
networking_tip: Smaller event = direct access to CSR leaders and social enterprise founders. Schedule 1:1s ahead of time.

title: AI for India's Next Billion: Intergenerational Insights for Inclusive and Future-Ready Growth
description:
AI is rapidly reshaping economies, public services, and governance. As the global population 
approaches 10 billion people by the next century, the stakes are uniquely high for the countries 
across Asia and Africa that will host many of the world's next billion people. Choices made today will 
shape the lives of those young people, and determine whether AI becomes a force for shared 
prosperity and public trust, or deepens inequality and power imbalances for generations.
speakers: Amandeep Singh Gill, United Nations; Amitabh Kant, NITI Aayog, GoI; Arunabha Ghosh, CEEW; Awais Ahmed, Pixxel Space Technologies; Claire Melamed, UN  Foundation; Kunalika Gautam, UN  Foundation; Ruchira Goyal, Sustainable Food  Systems; Safiya Husain, Karya; Vishal Tripathi, CEEW
