speakers: Mr. John Dickerson, Mozilla.ai; Ms. Chenai Chair, Masakhane African Languages Hub; Ms. Lea Gimpel, Digital Public Goods Alliance; Ms. Urvashi Aneja, Digital Futures Lab
summary_one_liner: Open-source tools and data as equalizers for global AI access
icebreaker: Urvashi Aneja's research on Global South AI equity—what's the biggest DPI gap you've seen in your region?
networking_tip: Grab a seat near gov policy advisors early; high-density decision makers leave quickly after panels end.

title: Democratizing Predictive AI: From Big Enterprises to MSMEs and Public Systems
description:
This panel will examine how predictive AI can be made accessible beyond large enterprises
to MSMEs, startups, and public systems in India. It will analyze why predictive intelligence
remains concentrated, the implications for competitiveness and inclusive growth, and how Time Series Foundation Models can lower adoption barriers. The discussion will surface
real deployment constraints: data quality, skills, cost, and infrastructure, and outline
practical pathways, ecosystem requirements, and the strategic importance of sovereign
predictive AI capabilities
speakers: Bhanu Potta, Birla AI Labs; Central Square Foundation; Dr. Saurabh Deshpande, Birla AI Labs; Goda Ramkumar, Swiggy; Mr. Piyush Prakashchandra Somani, ESDS Software Solution Ltd.; Richa Bajpai, CampusFund
knowledge_partners: Birla AI Labs, Office of Ananya Birla, Aditya Birla Group
summary_one_liner: Making predictive AI accessible to MSMEs and public systems
icebreaker: Dr. Saurabh Deshpande's work on MSMEs accessing predictive AI—what's blocking adoption in your sector?
networking_tip: Series A founders and enterprise leads sit separately; position yourself as a bridge during networking drinks.

title: AI and the Future of Creativity: Power, Originality, and Public Imagination
description: This session explores the paradox of AI-driven creativity—its power to democratize expression while endangering artists and cultural workers. Panelists will address authenticity, consent, and fairness in creative AI, equitable access for global creators, and safeguards against manipulation. Discussions will focus on AI's impact on livelihoods, data ethics, and open ecosystems, producing 5–7 guiding principles on provenance, consent, remuneration, transparency, and cultural infrastructure for global AI and creativity policy frameworks.
speakers: Divya Siddarth, Collective Intelligence Project; Nabiha Syed, Mozilla Foundation; Nikkhil Advani, G5a; Saranyan Vigraham, Meta
summary_one_liner: Navigating AI's paradox of democratized creativity versus artist displacement
icebreaker: Divya Siddarth's work on consent in AI creativity—how do you think platforms should handle artist attribution?
networking_tip: Find IP lawyers and creative technologists during breaks; they're your best connectors to artist advocacy networks.

title: Secure AI Development: Understanding the Security Risks and Developing Advice and Global Technical Standards
description: Discover how the UK Government is working with global partners to understand the risks and shape the future of secure AI. The UK AI Security Institute (AISI) will introduce the key findings from its Frontier AI Trends Report. The session will showcase the work of the UK government, including the NCSC, to collaborate with global industry, governments and academia to produce security requirements and drive the development of the world's first global AI security standard.
speakers: Mr Oliver Brooks, UK Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO); Mr Oliver Jones, UK AI Security Institute (AISI)
summary_one_liner: UK AISI unveils frontier AI security standards and risk findings
icebreaker: UK AISI's frontier AI security findings—which risk area concerns your organization most?
networking_tip: Government and CISO attendees are high-value but leave fast. Attend the pre-panel reception for 1-on-1 access.

title: AI-based Knowledge Acquisition Tools for Health and Education
description: This session discusses the use of AI-based Knowledge Acquisition Tools to enable advanced Healthcare services
speakers: Dr Ali Irani, Super Speciality Hospital, Mumbai; Dr Gaurav S Desai, PD Hinduja, Breach Candy, Gleneagles, KEM Hospital); Dr Pawan Saharan, CEO Biomix Network Inc USA
summary_one_liner: Deploy AI knowledge tools to transform healthcare and education delivery
icebreaker: Ask Dr. Ali Irani about real-world AI adoption challenges in Super Speciality Hospital workflows.
networking_tip: Identify hospital IT leads and healthcare vendors for B2B partnerships.

title: YUVAi: Global Youth Challenge - Grand Finale
description: This session will feature presentations by selected teams across three panels, showcasing their ideas and solutions. Each segment will be followed by jury interactions and questions, enabling deeper evaluation, feedback, and discussion.
speakers: Sh. Mohammed Y. Safirulla K, Director, IndiaAI Mission, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology; Deepak Bagla, Mission Director, Atal Innovation Mission (AIM); Ivana Bartoletti, Vice-President, Global Chief Privacy and  AI Governance Officer, Wipro (TBC); Apurv Agrawal, CEO & Co-Founder, SquadStack.ai (TBC); Kirthiga Reddy, CEO & Co-Founder, Verix; Jeet Wagh, Co-founder, Ideabaaz ; Shradha Sharma, Founder & CEO, YourStory (TBC) ; Kartik Suri, General Manager, IndiaAI Mission
summary_one_liner: Youth-led AI solutions showcase with government and innovation judges
icebreaker: Tell Mohammed Y. Safirulla K about your team's AI solution and get IndiaAI Mission feedback.
networking_tip: Pitch your idea to Deepak Bagla (AIM) for accelerator program eligibility.

title: AI for ALL: Final Showcase
description: The AI for ALL: Global Impact Challenge showcase will trace the journey from its October launch to the selection of 20 standout finalists from a competitive global pool. A dynamic, jury-led panel will explore how AI can drive development across the Global South, addressing equitable access and responsible deployment. The Top 20 teams will pitch their solutions, with the jury selecting and announcing the final 10 winners.
speakers: Mr. Amitabh Nag, CEO, Bhashini; Ms. Kavita Bhatia, COO, IndiaAI ; Mr. Tomoyuki Yamada, Senior Director of Office for STI & DX, JICA​; Mr. Karan Mohla, General Partner, B Capital; Mr. Ramanan Ramanathan, Mission Governing Board, IndiaAI; Mr. Mudit Kumar, Co-Founder and COO, Ideabaaz; Ms. Courtney O'Donnell, Global Impact Lead, Anthropic; Mr. Gaurav Jha, Project Leader, BCG
summary_one_liner: Global South AI finalists pitch for equitable development impact
icebreaker: Ask Karan Mohla (B Capital) about investment criteria for Global South AI startups.
networking_tip: Connect finalists with Bhashini's Amitabh Nag for multilingual AI partnerships.

title: Advancing AI Readiness and Adoption in Manufacturing MSMEs: Official Launch
description: This session marks the official launch of the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology's IndiaAI study on "Advancing AI Readiness and Adoption in Manufacturing MSMEs." Bringing together senior government leaders and ecosystem partners, it will examine how India's MSME sector can prepare for AI at scale—strengthening competitiveness, regulatory compliance, traceability, and sustainable growth in an increasingly demanding global market.
speakers: Shri Abhishek Singh, Government of India; Shri Bhuvnesh Kumar, Government of India; Shri Manoj Joshi, Government of India; Shri Rohit Kansal, Government of India; Shri S. Krishnan, Government of India; Shri S.C.L. Das, Government of India; Smt. Deepa Karthykeyan, Athena Infonomics
summary_one_liner: Official launch: AI adoption roadmap for India's manufacturing MSME sector
icebreaker: Ask Shri S. Krishnan about MSME AI readiness assessment findings and policy recommendations.
networking_tip: Engage government officials on MSME digitalization grants and support programs.

title: YUVAi: Global Youth Challenge - Grand Finale
description: This session will feature presentations by selected teams across three panels, showcasing their ideas and solutions. Each segment will be followed by jury interactions and questions, enabling deeper evaluation, feedback, and discussion.
speakers: Sh. Mohammed Y. Safirulla K, Director, IndiaAI Mission, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology; Deepak Bagla, Mission Director, Atal Innovation Mission (AIM); Ivana Bartoletti, Vice-President, Global Chief Privacy and  AI Governance Officer, Wipro (TBC); Apurv Agrawal, CEO & Co-Founder, SquadStack.ai (TBC); Kirthiga Reddy, CEO & Co-Founder, Verix; Jeet Wagh, Co-founder, Ideabaaz ; Shradha Sharma, Founder & CEO, YourStory (TBC) ; Kartik Suri, General Manager, IndiaAI Mission
summary_one_liner: Youth-led AI solutions showcase with government and innovation judges
icebreaker: Tell Mohammed Y. Safirulla K about your team's AI solution and get IndiaAI Mission feedback.
networking_tip: Pitch your idea to Deepak Bagla (AIM) for accelerator program eligibility.

title: AI for ALL: Final Showcase
description: The AI for ALL: Global Impact Challenge showcase will trace the journey from its October launch to the selection of 20 standout finalists from a competitive global pool. A dynamic, jury-led panel will explore how AI can drive development across the Global South, addressing equitable access and responsible deployment. The Top 20 teams will pitch their solutions, with the jury selecting and announcing the final 10 winners.
speakers: Mr. Amitabh Nag, CEO, Bhashini; Ms. Kavita Bhatia, COO, IndiaAI ; Mr. Tomoyuki Yamada, Senior Director of Office for STI & DX, JICA​; Mr. Karan Mohla, General Partner, B Capital; Mr. Ramanan Ramanathan, Mission Governing Board, IndiaAI; Mr. Mudit Kumar, Co-Founder and COO, Ideabaaz; Ms. Courtney O'Donnell, Global Impact Lead, Anthropic; Mr. Gaurav Jha, Project Leader, BCG
summary_one_liner: Global South AI finalists pitch for equitable development impact
icebreaker: Ask Karan Mohla (B Capital) about investment criteria for Global South AI startups.
networking_tip: Connect finalists with Bhashini's Amitabh Nag for multilingual AI partnerships.

title: From Models to the Masses: Deploying AI for Climate Resilience
description: The session aims to demonstrate and deliberate the potential of how cutting-edge climate research, AI models, and planetary-scale predictions can directly strengthen on-ground resilience. By showcasing tools that offer hyperlocal insights on floods, heat and emerging risks, the session explores practical pathways to integrate science, technology, and policy for faster, more effective local action. It highlights how AI can empower governments, communities, and institutions to plan smarter, respond earlier, and build a climate-ready future.
speakers: Ashley Thomas; Dr Arunabha Ghosh; Dr Ram Prasath Manohar V; Prof Manabendra Saharia; Rajroshan Sawhney; Vaibhav Chugh
knowledge_partners: Council on Energy Environment and Water (CEEW)
summary_one_liner: Hyperlocal AI climate models driving on-ground disaster resilience
icebreaker: Dr. Arunabha Ghosh's hyperlocal flood prediction models—how are you integrating hyperlocal data into your systems?
networking_tip: Climate scientists and disaster officials work together; insert yourself into their conversations with specific model questions.

title: Democratizing AI for the Last Mile:Language, Access and Trust at Scale
description: The session advances the conversation from democratizing AI access to enabling meaningful last-mile adoption, where inclusion, usability, and public trust define real impact. It explores how language AI and foundation models can serve as shared national digital infrastructure, powering governance and cultural services at scale. Emphasizing trust-by-design, it highlights transparent, accountable, human-centric AI and collaboration across industry, government platforms, and public institutions to responsibly scale inclusive AI.
speakers: Amitabh Nag; Brijendra Kumar; Calista Redmond; Harsh Dhand; Pier Stefano; Shankar Maruwada; Srinivas Voruganti
summary_one_liner: Language AI as national infrastructure for last-mile inclusion
icebreaker: Amitabh Nag on Indic language models at scale—what's your biggest last-mile adoption blocker?
networking_tip: GovTech and NLP researchers naturally cluster. Position near Srinivas Voruganti for KPMG partnership connections.

title: Diagnosing the Future: AI Transforming Healthcare Systems
description: Artificial Intelligence is reshaping India's healthcare system, beginning with medical technologies and diagnostics and extending to hospital operations, clinical decision support, research, and preventive care. AI-enabled imaging, IVDs, and analytics are improving accuracy, access, and system efficiency, particularly in resource-constrained settings. This session will examine policy, governance, and collaboration pathways to responsibly scale AI across diagnostics, care delivery and research, supporting a resilient and future-ready healthcare ecosystem
speakers: Dr Krithika Rangarajan, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Delhi; Dr Vidur Mahajan, Carpl.ai; Mr Adarsh Srivastava, Roche Diagnostics R&D; Mr Apoorva Patni, Patni Healthcare Ltd.; Mr John W Schaeffler, GE HealthCare Foundation; Shri G. Veerapandian, Health & Family Welfare Department and Mission Director, National Health Mission, Government of Andhra Pradesh; Shri Kiran Gopal Vaska (IAS), ABDM, National Health Authority, GoI
summary_one_liner: FICCI-led dialogue on scaling AI diagnostics across India's healthcare
icebreaker: Dr. Vidur Mahajan, which diagnostic AI use cases see fastest adoption in India's hospital networks?
networking_tip: Hospital CEOs and MedTech founders cluster—demonstrate clinical validation data to secure pilot agreements.

title: Safe and Trusted AI: Standardization in the age of LLMs, Generative and Agentic AI
description: The rapid deployment of LLMs, Generative, and Agentic AI offers immense productivity gains alongside significant concerns. This panel identifies opportunities and challenges in AI adoption, highlighting how standardization enables responsible innovation. Featuring experts from industry, academia, and policy, the session explores the current status of AI standards and the urgent need for further frameworks. The goal is to ensure AI's responsible use for positive societal impact through a collaborative, standardized approach.
speakers: Mr. Abhishek Aggarwal, Ministry of Electronics & IT, GoI; Mr. Ashish Tewari, Infosys; Mr. Rohit Israni, INCITS/AI; Mr. Sridhar Chimalakonda, IIT (IIT) Tirupati, India; Adjunct Faculty, University of Waterloo, Canada; Mr. Tim McGarr, British Standards Institution (BSI); Mrs Reena Garg, Bureau of Indian Standards; Ms. Gayathri Ekambaram, Tata Consultancy Services
summary_one_liner: Setting AI standards for LLMs and agentic systems via BIS
icebreaker: Tim McGarr, what's BIS's priority for AI standardization to protect enterprises deploying agentic systems?
networking_tip: Standards delegates and compliance officers attend—frame your governance questions around specific BIS implementation timelines.

title: Women at the Frontline of AI: Reimagining Skilling for India's Community Health Workforce
description: This session examines how AI can strengthen India's women-led community health workforce through inclusive skilling and real-world deployment. Drawing on large-scale use of LLM-powered tools with ASHAs and ANMs across multiple states, the session explores productivity gains, quality of care, and equitable AI access in rural settings. The discussion highlights practical pathways for building a scalable, gender-responsive, AI-enabled frontline workforce in India and globally.
speakers: Amrita Mahale, ARMMAN; Ashish Srivastava, AI Innovation for Inclusion Initiative, IIIT Bangalore; Hamid Adbullah, Khushi Baby; Tanusree Deb Barma, UIDAI
summary_one_liner: LLM-powered tools empowering India's women community health workers
icebreaker: Amrita, what surprised you most deploying LLM tools with ASHA workers in the field?
networking_tip: Connect with public health directors early—they approve real-world pilot deployments for community health innovations.

title: AI Compute beyond GPUs
description: This session explores the critical infrastructure powering inclusive AI ecosystems. It will examine compute networking, power, systems design and skills as enablers of innovation and economic growth. Participants will identify infrastructure bottlenecks, discuss pathways to democratize access to hardware and R&D and connect distributed, energy-efficient infrastructure to resilience. Through examples of open innovation and public–private collaboration, the session will generate actionable insights for policymakers and ecosystem builders seeking scalable, equitable AI infrastructure across regions globally.
speakers: Abhishek Biswal, Airtel - Xtelify; Becky Fraser, Qualcomm; Bhawna Agarwal, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, India; Jason Oxman, Information Technology Industry Council; Navin Bishnoi, Marvell; Navin Bishnoi, Marvell; Sujith Babu, Ciena; Wilson White, Google; Wilson White, Google
summary_one_liner: Beyond GPUs: distributed compute infrastructure for equitable AI access
icebreaker: Ask Wilson White why compute infrastructure is the overlooked foundation for AI equity.
networking_tip: Chat with infrastructure leaders—they're investing in underserved markets globally.

title: Fireside Chat on AI/ML Driven Virtual Immersive Autonomous Personalized Learning
description: This fireside chat draws from personal insights and experiences of the panel members and Aten Inc.'s AI/ML-driven virtual immersive, autonomous, personalized learning solutions to scale talent development in India, particularly for rural, remote and underserved youth in sectors like AI, Semiconductors, Manufacturing, and Telecom to reflect on the summit's core "Chakras" of Human Capital Inclusion, Safe and Trusted AI, Resilience, Innovation & Efficiency, Science, Democratizing AI Resources, and AI for Growth and Social Good.
speakers: Ajith Sundaresh, Fusion Kaapi; Arvind Kumar, Eisner Amper; George Varghese, Independant; Latha Elizabeth Koshi, Aten Inc.; Thomas K Vaidhyan, Aten Inc.
summary_one_liner: VR-powered AI training for rural youth in semiconductors and telecom
icebreaker: Ajith, which rural demographics are seeing the fastest skill gains with immersive VR training?
networking_tip: L&D heads attend for talent solutions—have concrete ROI metrics ready on training time/cost reduction.

title: Data Governance at the Intersection of Digital Public Infrastructure and Artificial Intelligence
description: Digital public infrastructures (DPIs) such as national digital identity systems, payments rails, data-trust frameworks and shared open datasets are rapidly becoming the foundation for AI  development and deployment. When AI systems are trained on or linked through DPIs, the governance of data becomes critical: who collects data, how it's aggregated, for what purposes, with what safeguards.
speakers: (Moderator) Prateek Waghre, Tech Global Institute, India; (Moderator) Prateek Waghre, Tech Global Institute, India; Chinasa T. Okolo, United Nations; Marianne Diaz Hernandez, Researcher on digital rights expert on digital public infrastructure, Venezuela; Marianne Diaz Hernandez, Researcher on   digital public infrastructure, Venezuela; Smriti Parsheera, Lawyer and public policy researcher, India; Vinicius de Faria Silva, Government of Brazil; Vinicius de Faria Silva, Government of Brazil
summary_one_liner: Governing data flows where DPI meets AI at national scale
icebreaker: Chinasa Okolo on DPI data governance—how are you balancing AI access with data protection in your system?
networking_tip: Data protection officers and policy researchers attend; smaller panel means moderator Sabhanaz is very accessible post-talk.

title: The NxtWave–OpenAI National Hackathon Grand Finale
description: This session marks the grand finale of a nationwide AI buildathon initiative, celebrating participation from over 26,000 students across seven states. More than 1,400 teams developed AI solutions through regional buildathons held across Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Delhi NCR, Rajasthan, and Maharashtra. The session will showcase selected solutions, share key learnings from the programme, and conclude with the felicitation of finalist teams and partners involved.
speakers: Bonnie Chatterjee, OpenAI; Dr. Vineet Joshi, University Grants Commission (UGC), Ministry of Education; Jitin Prasada, Ministry of Commerce and Industry and Ministry of Electronics and IT; Prof. Yogesh Singh, AICTE, Ministry of Education; Rahul Attaluri, Nxtwave
summary_one_liner: 26,000 students showcase AI solutions in OpenAI-backed national finale
icebreaker: Prof. Yogesh Singh, what caliber of AI solutions did the 26,000 students build across seven states?
networking_tip: University deans and talent scouts jam here—demo your best student projects in networking zones to get scouted.

title: Deep Tech and AI Investing in India: Current and Future States
description: India is entering a new phase in its transition towards a product-innovation economy, with deep tech and AI playing an increasingly important role. This panel will launch a report offering a data-driven view of capital flows, funding gaps, and ecosystem maturity. Speakers will examine AI as a horizontal enabler across deep tech sectors and discuss policy and investment priorities to support capital access and innovation at scale.
speakers: Gopal Jain, Gaja Capital; Nishith Desai, Nishith Desai & Co.; Ravi Kiran Vadapally, Premji Invest; Siddarth Pai, 3one4 Capital; Sneh Vaswani, Miko; Sudhir Sethi, Chiratae Ventures India Advisors
summary_one_liner: Top VCs map India's deep tech funding landscape and gaps
icebreaker: Siddarth Pai, what deep tech categories are VCs most actively funding in India's next wave?
networking_tip: VC-heavy room—have your Series A/B thesis on one slide. Approach fund managers during report launch discussion.

title: Global Dialogue on AI Usage-Data for Labour Market Resilience
description: The convening will bring together international economists, AI research organisations, global institutions, think tanks, and delegates from countries attending the AI Impact Summit 2026. As governments develop AI workforce transition strategies, access to local AI usage data is increasingly important. The event will examine why such data matters, what level of granularity is needed, and why countries must have reliable access to it.
speakers: Ambassador Philip Thigo, H.E the President of the Republic of Kenya.; Bharat Chandar, Stanford Digital Economy Lab, Stanford University; Cina Lawson, Togo; Hector de Rivoire, Microsoft's Office of Responsible AI; Prof. Robert Trager, Oxford Martin AI Governance Initiative at the University of Oxford; Yoshua Bengio, Université de Montréal
summary_one_liner: Yoshua Bengio and global leaders tackle AI labour market data gaps
icebreaker: Yoshua Bengio, what labour market shifts concern you most as AI scales globally?
networking_tip: Heavy-hitter event with ministers and economists—arrive early to secure 1:1s with government policy advisors on workforce transition.

title: Education for Social Empowerment: Building Resilient, Inclusive Learning Systems
description: This session explores how education systems can be redesigned to be more inclusive, resilient, and responsive using digital public infrastructure and adaptive learning approaches. Speakers will share field learnings from education reforms, community-led models, and digital interventions that aim to improve equity and learning outcomes at scale
speakers: Jagadish Babu, EkStep Foundation; Mr. Benjamin Piper, Gates Foundation; Mr. Cem Mete, World Bank; Mr. Mitesh Khapra, AI4Bharat; Mr. Vineet Nayar, Sampark foundation; Ms. Yogita Rana, Govt of Telangana
summary_one_liner: Redesigning education with adaptive learning and DPI at scale
icebreaker: Vineet Nayar, how is EkStep tackling adaptive learning at scale across India's diverse classrooms?
networking_tip: Target education ministry officials during breaks—they control budget allocation for digital infrastructure.

title: Policies for Social and Economic Resilience in the AI Age: Global South Perspectives
description: Bringing insights from new research, the experts in this session will discuss key recommendations that can guide leaders in navigating labor & economic policymaking and empowering workers in the age of AI. This dialogue will reflect upon how the Global South can build institutional capacity and shape inclusive economic systems to ensure that AI-driven technological change can facilitate shared prosperity.
speakers: Adrian Brown, Windfall Trust; Kô Goma, Togo Ministry of Public Service Efficiency and Digital Transformation; Osama Manzar, Digital Empowerment Foundation; Rebecca Finlay, Partnership on AI; Sambhav Jain, BCG; Stella Luk, GiveDirectly; Thomas Schneider, Swiss Federal Office of Communications
summary_one_liner: Global South labor policy insights for equitable AI-driven economic resilience
icebreaker: Ask Osama Manzar how Digital Empowerment Foundation is preparing workers for AI transition.
networking_tip: Connect with Kô Goma for insights on African policy frameworks and innovation opportunities.

title: Trustworthy AI Investments : Capital Allocations as AI Governance
description: This panel examines how venture capital, sovereign funds, and philanthropy are shaping AI governance, exploring trustworthy AI investment frameworks, transparency in capital flows, and aligning AI innovation with long-term public interest.
speakers: Amir Banifatemi, Cognizant; Balamaran Ravindran, CeRAI - IIT Madras; Joanna Shields, UK Government; Karine Perset, OECD; Mohamed Nanabhay, Mozilla Ventures; Sophie Fallaha, CEIMIA; Wan Sie Lee, Info-Communications Media Development Authority (IMDA)
summary_one_liner: Capital flows shaping AI governance and trustworthy investment frameworks
icebreaker: Ask Joanna Shields how UK policy informs OECD's governance frameworks
networking_tip: Connect VCs to OECD representatives during breaks for policy-capital alignment insights

title: From Algorithms to ASHAs: Implementing Impactful AI at the Grassroots
description: India's digital public infrastructure has created unprecedented opportunities to deploy AI in healthcare but scaling solutions beyond pilots remains a challenge. This panel brings together leaders from public health, medicine, and data science to examine what it truly takes to implement AI at the grassroots. Drawing on real-world case studies and research, the session explores data readiness, ethics, workforce capacity, and system integration needed to responsibly translate AI innovation into equitable health outcomes.
speakers: Dr. Anurag Agrawal, Biosciences and Health Research, Ashoka University; Dr. Aparna Hegde, ARMMAN; Dr. Mithun Kumar Mitra, Department of Physics, IIT Bombay; Dr. Smisha Agarwal, Center for Global Digital Health Innovation (CGDHI); Urvashi Wattal, Evidence & Impact, Khushi Baby
summary_one_liner: Scaling grassroots AI in Indian healthcare beyond pilot projects
icebreaker: Ask Dr. Agrawal about bridging clinical validation with scalability in India's health stack
networking_tip: Exchange contact info with public health practitioners interested in tech partnerships

title: Diplomacy and Development in the Era of AI: Turning Innovation into Impact
description: AI has evolved beyond pilot projects to fundamentally transform business operations, workflows, and value creation. As adoption accelerates, leadership faces mounting pressure to pair innovation with strong governance embedded in corporate strategy. Organizations need modern, trust-based frameworks to ensure accountability and responsible decision-making. With rapid growth in markets like India, scaling AI demands the right leadership, operating models, and technical foundations. Robust governance becomes a catalyst, enabling secure, aligned, and confident AI deployment across the enterprise.
room: Hall No. 3 First Floor - Session Hall 4
speakers: H.E. Amandeep Singh Gill, Under-Secretary-General and Special Envoy of the United Nations for Digital and Emerging Technologies
summary_one_liner: UN leadership on AI diplomacy and governance-driven innovation strategy
icebreaker: Ask H.E. Gill how emerging tech diplomacy shapes national AI strategies globally
networking_tip: Prepare policy alignment questions for UN Special Envoy before the session

title: Open-source Tooling for Safe, Secure and Trustworthy AI
summary_one_liner: Open-source tools for safe and secure AI systems
icebreaker: Discuss preferred open-source frameworks for AI safety testing with other engineers
networking_tip: Find contributors to open-source safety projects for potential collaboration

title: AI in Work: Humans, AI, or Both?
description: How can AI help in enhancing recruitment pipelines to improve efficiency and productivity of firms? This session, featuring a presentation by an international researcher on a randomised evaluation on leveraging AI tools to improve teacher hiring, followed by a panel discussion with leading practitioners. This discussion will examine how AI can reshape recruitment pipelines, skill matching and workforce productivity. Participants will explore how evidence can inform the design and adoption of AI tools that enhance skills, productivity, and worker wellbeing.
speakers: David Yanagizawa-Drott, University of Zurich; Elizabeth Kelly, Anthropic; Murugan Vasudevan, Veddis; Shankar Maruwada, EkStep Foundation
summary_one_liner: J-PAL evidence on AI-augmented hiring and workforce productivity
icebreaker: David Yanagizawa-Drott, what did your RCT reveal about AI's actual impact on hiring quality vs. efficiency?
networking_tip: CHROs and HR Tech founders both attend—ask CHROs directly about their pilot evaluation timelines to pitch solutions.

title: Investing in Bharat: Regional AI Hubs and Inclusive Growth
description: This session examines how AI is transforming education, industry, and institutions at scale. It will explore borderless learning enabled by AI, industry perspectives on adoption and competitiveness, and the integration of AI with blockchain to rewire institutional systems. The discussion will focus on translating policy intent into practical, secure, and scalable implementations across sectors and ecosystems.
room: Hall No. 5 First Floor - Session Hall 1
speakers:
Sh. Arvind Kumar, Director General, STPI


; Dr. Deepak Bagla,Mission Director AIM, NITI Aayog; Ms. Amneet P. Kumar,  Principal Secretary to the Govt. of Haryana; Sh. Shri Jitendra Kumar, MD, BIRAC, Dept. of Biotechnology
summary_one_liner: NITI Aayog and STPI chart regional AI hubs for Bharat
icebreaker: How is your Tier-2 city positioning itself in NITI Aayog's regional AI hub race?
networking_tip: STPI directors and AIM officers here green-light grants—have your inclusive growth metrics documented.

title: Engineering Digital Trust in the Age of AI - Blockchain as the Backbone of India's Intelligence Infrastructure
description: Discover how blockchain can serve as the backbone of India's intelligence infrastructure—strengthening digital trust in the age of AI. Sessions explore secure data exchange, transparent governance, decentralized identity, and resilient innovation ecosystems, highlighting how incubators, enterprises, and missions can leverage blockchain to ensure integrity, accountability, and sovereignty in India's AI‑driven future.
room: Hall No. 4 First Floor - Session Hall 2
speakers:
Dr. Shiv Sharma, BFPF








; Prof. Satya.N.Gupta, BFPF, SAU; Dr. Praveen Mishra, Director ICT, South Asian University (SAU)
; Sh. Akhilesh, Shrivastva Chairman ITS; Dr. Akhil Damodaran, Director, SCMHRD Pune ; Prof. Arunabha Mukhopadhyay, IIML; Mr. Anurag Agrawal, Founder & CEO, DataBloc ; Prof. John Augustine, IITB; Mr. Kamlesh Nagware, Co-Founder, FSV Labs; Ms. Garima Singh, CEO, Bitviraj Technology
; Mr. Niraj Gupta, International Technologist; Mr. V. Aravind, Executive Chairman, BFPF
summary_one_liner: Blockchain meets AI for India's sovereign digital trust infrastructure
icebreaker: With Dr. Shiv Sharma present, what's the real use case for blockchain in India's AI infrastructure?
networking_tip: IITB and IIML faculty here mentor web3 founders—pitch your decentralized AI concept directly.

title: Tata Bharat YUVAi Hackathon
description:
What happens when 2,000 college students, non-coders, build working apps in just three
hours? Find out in this session, where Arts, Science, and Commerce students will go from picking a real-
world problem to creating a digital prototype, all guided by AI that works in Indian languages. Students
choose challenges across healthcare, education, agriculture, and civic life, then use step-by-step AI tools
to research, brainstorm, and build — no programming experience needed. It's a live demonstration of
what India's next million digital creators could look like.
speakers: Srividhya Muralidharan, Tata Consultancy Services
summary_one_liner: 2,000 non-coder students build AI apps live in three hours
icebreaker: How did you help students pick real-world problems for their 3-hour no-code builds, Srividhya?
networking_tip: Mentor the winning teams during demo presentations—student innovators remember who believed in them first.

title: AI Masterclass in Public Services
description: This is a practical, hands-on, session, facilitated by Tata Consultancy Services, where participants will build applications in grievance management and welfare scheme eligibility, empowering participants to build their own AI applications with zero coding. This Masterclass will provide participants with a clear framework for developing public sector applications that prioritize AI, responsibility, and data sovereignty. It will also offer an accessible introduction to building practical solutions using large language models through effective prompting techniques.
speakers: Arun Ramchandran, Tata Consultancy Services; Sankha Som, Tata Consultancy Services
summary_one_liner: TCS hands-on workshop: build no-code AI apps for governance
icebreaker: Arun, what's the most common grievance management challenge you see across Indian public services?
networking_tip: Arrive early to chat with TCS facilitators before hands-on coding starts—they control group assignments.

title: Building India's Most Deployment-Ready AI State: The Tamil Nadu Model
description: The session will highlight Tamil Nadu's approach towards operationalising AI at scale, with emphasis on deployment readiness, public infrastructure, and real-world outcomes across sectors.
room: Hall No. 4 First Floor - Session Hall 3
summary_one_liner: Tamil Nadu's operational AI deployment at scale across sectors
icebreaker: Ask about Tamil Nadu's deployment-readiness metrics across public sectors
networking_tip: Connect with state officials on AI infrastructure to explore regional partnerships

title: YUVAi: Global Youth Challenge - Grand Finale
description: This session will feature presentations by selected teams across three panels, showcasing their ideas and solutions. Each segment will be followed by jury interactions and questions, enabling deeper evaluation, feedback, and discussion.
speakers: Sh. Mohammed Y. Safirulla K, Director, IndiaAI Mission, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology; Deepak Bagla, Mission Director, Atal Innovation Mission (AIM); Ivana Bartoletti, Vice-President, Global Chief Privacy and  AI Governance Officer, Wipro (TBC); Apurv Agrawal, CEO & Co-Founder, SquadStack.ai (TBC); Kirthiga Reddy, CEO & Co-Founder, Verix; Jeet Wagh, Co-founder, Ideabaaz ; Shradha Sharma, Founder & CEO, YourStory (TBC) ; Kartik Suri, General Manager, IndiaAI Mission
summary_one_liner: Global youth showcase innovative AI solutions for emerging challenges
icebreaker: Ask Mohammed Safirulla about IndiaAI's most promising cohort trends this year
networking_tip: Connect with mission directors to understand funding pathways for scaled winners

title: Public Distribution Systems Reforms – AI/ML and Computer Vision for Smart Logistics and Consumer Welfare
description: This session will focus on applications of AI/ML and computer vision in public distribution systems, with emphasis on warehouse monitoring and predictive price intelligence. Drawing on large-scale implementation experiences and perspectives from multilateral institutions, the discussion will examine scalable models, responsible AI frameworks, and financing approaches to support food security and consumer welfare in developing economies.
speakers: Aditya, Vexoo Labs; G Kalyana Chakravarthy, Deloitte, India; Hardik Dave, RoadVision AI Private Limited; Lakshmi Venkat, Real Variable Digital Asset Services Pvt. Ltd.; Nozomi Hashimoto, UN World Food Programme, India; Partha Sai Surathu, RNIT AI Solutions Limited; Shri Nadendla Manohar, Government of Andhra Pradesh; Treasa Mathew, IFC
summary_one_liner: Computer vision and AI reforming India's public food distribution chain
icebreaker: Hardik Dave on warehouse computer vision—what's your accuracy threshold for food security applications?
networking_tip: State supply chain officers + GovTech founders both here. Prep demo video to pitch logistics solutions.

title: Frugal AI and Quantum-Ready Systems: Driving Growth, Impact, and the SDGs
description: This session explores how cost-efficient and future-ready technologies can drive sustainable growth and social impact. Grounded in practical frameworks for responsible innovation and informed by emerging quantum initiatives, the discussion will focus on affordable AI adoption in the public sector, lifecycle evaluation of advanced technologies, and the development of resilient national digital infrastructure. Participants will examine early preparation for the quantum era and strategies for linking technology deployment to public value and SDG outcomes.
speakers: Anusha Dandapani; Jagadish Babu; Sameer Chauhan; Serish Gandikota; Sridhar C V
knowledge_partners: Frugal AI Hub at Cambridge Judge Business School
summary_one_liner: Cambridge-backed frugal AI and quantum readiness for the Global South
icebreaker: Anusha, which SDG has the highest ROI for frugal AI interventions in India?
networking_tip: Quantum researchers cluster early—sit near Cambridge speakers to catch post-talk technical discussions.

title: AI for Resilient India: Driving Innovation and Efficiency at Scale
description: This session explores how artificial intelligence can strengthen national resilience by transforming industries, governance, and digital infrastructure. It highlights the role of AI in driving large-scale innovation, improving operational efficiency, and enabling data-driven decision-making. The discussion will examine scalable AI adoption, enterprise transformation, and cross-sector collaboration, while showcasing real-world applications that accelerate India's journey from experimentation to impactful, production-ready AI solutions.
speakers: Dr. Gowtham Mamidisetti; Dr. Prasad Patibandla; Dr.Chilaka Mahesh; Kalyan Prasad; Madhu Vadlamani; Prof. Dr. Kasa Ravindra; Sonu Kumar; Venkata Srinivasa Rao Talatam
summary_one_liner: Enterprise AI transformation case studies from India's innovation ecosystem
icebreaker: Dr. Gowtham, which Industry 4.0 sector saw the biggest efficiency gains from your scalable AI framework?
networking_tip: Engineering faculty attend this—ask them about their student placement pipelines for AI roles.

title: From Policy to Practice: Governing AI for Global Impact
description: Trust is the infrastructure of AI adoption. This session focuses on what it takes in 2026 to govern AI for real world benefit, especially in the Global Majority. We move from principles to practice through sandboxes with clear entry and exit criteria, independent evaluation and red teaming, and reusable assurance artifacts such as model cards, audit logs, and incident reporting. We ask where interoperability and collaboration accelerate impact, and where sovereignty and geopolitics create friction.
speakers: Ashish Aggarwal; Gail Kent; Ivana Bartoletti; Jules Polonetsky; Wifredo "Wifi" Fernández
summary_one_liner: Nasscom-led practical AI governance: sandboxes, red-teaming, model cards
icebreaker: Jules, how do red teams stress-test AI models before deployment in regulated industries?
networking_tip: High decision-maker density—position yourself near Nasscom policy reps to discuss regulatory sandbox access.

title: Navigating AI-DPI Geopolitics: An Autonomous and Strategic Approach for the Global Majority
description: As India and other countries integrate AI into Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI), they confront critical geopolitical challenges related to sovereignty, reducing dependency, and enabling global cooperation—while preserving openness and interoperability. Held alongside the India AI Impact Summit, this session will explore public-interest AI-DPI pathways beyond major power centric technology ecosystems. Drawing on global case studies and expert dialogue, it will examine geopolitical implications, distill lessons for the Global Majority, identify mechanisms for collaboration, and propose recommendations for DPI stakeholders and technology funders for 2026.
speakers: Dr. Mehdi Snene; Jane Munga; Kunal Raj Barua; Rowan Wilkinson; Sourav Das
summary_one_liner: Chatham House explores AI-DPI sovereignty beyond superpower tech stacks
icebreaker: Sourav, how can countries reduce AI dependency without fragmenting the global tech ecosystem?
networking_tip: Foreign policy strategists attend—join the geopolitics roundtable to pitch sovereign tech frameworks.

title: Pathways for Equitable AI Compute Access
description: The session will present a policy framework for a shared compute hub model that entails regionally shared, jointly financed, and transparently governed AI compute infrastructure. It will convene leading policymakers, researchers, and industry experts to discuss the model's viability, financing, and governance, and to use it as a case study to explore an 'equitable compute agenda' as a potential outcome of the India AI Summit 2026.
speakers: Mr. Hector De Rivoire; Mr. Robert F. Trager; Mr. Rohit Kumar; Mr. Sunil Gupta; Ms.  PeiChin Tay; Ms. Linda Griffin; Ms. Sangeeta Gupta
summary_one_liner: Oxford Martin proposes shared compute hubs for equitable AI access
icebreaker: Rohit, which multilateral finance bodies are backing shared compute hub models in South Asia?
networking_tip: Cloud provider strategy leads need partnerships—sit with them during infrastructure breakout sessions.

title: Advancing Rural AI Access and Ethical AI Governance
description: This initiative focuses on expanding equitable access to artificial intelligence for rural and underserved communities while promoting responsible and ethical AI adoption. By strengthening local capacity through education, digital infrastructure, and teacher enablement, it ensures that AI tools are used transparently, inclusively, and for public good. The approach balances innovation with accountability, empowering communities to leverage AI for learning, livelihoods, and social development without widening existing digital divides.
speakers: Arun Poddar; Chaula Diwanji; Kishore Kumar; Meenakshi Uberoi; Nathan Metsala; Payal Rajpal
summary_one_liner: Bridging rural digital divides with ethical AI and robotics education
icebreaker: Arun, how do you teach AI concepts to rural teachers with limited digital infrastructure?
networking_tip: CSR directors control education budgets—ask district education officers about their robotics rollout timelines.

title: AI for Secure India: Combating AI-Enabled Cybercrime, Deepfakes, Darkweb Threats and Data Breaches
description: This session by the Future Crime Research Foundation examines how artificial intelligence is reshaping the cyber threat landscape in India. Titled "AI for Secure India: Combating AI-Enabled Cybercrime, Deepfakes, Darkweb Threats & Data Breaches", the discussion will unpack emerging attack vectors, real-world cases, and defensive strategies. Moderated by Prof. Triveni Singh, Ex-IPS officer and Chief Mentor, FCRF, the session focuses on policy, investigation, and resilience across government, enterprises, and law enforcement ecosystems, nationwide stakeholders.
speakers: Deepak Kumar Singh; Rakesh Maheshwari; Sapna Bansal; Tarun Wig; Triveni Singh; Vivek Sood
summary_one_liner: Ex-IPS-led deep dive into AI-powered cybercrime and darkweb defense
icebreaker: Deepak Kumar Singh's work on darkweb threats—what's the most surprising AI tactic you've seen criminals use?
networking_tip: High decision-maker density: arrive early to connect with CISOs before the technical deep-dives begin.

title: Reducing AI-Driven Digital Harms for Minors: Platform Accountability, Age Assurance, and Safety-by-Design
description: Over the past decade, digital platforms and AI have transformed how children learn, socialise, and access information, including within schools. While offering benefits, these technologies also heighten risks such as harmful content exposure, harassment, privacy loss, addictive design, and mental health impacts, with generative AI amplifying scale. This panel explores global policy approaches—duty-of-care, age-appropriate design, age assurance, recommender governance, and education safeguards—to balance innovation with stronger online safety for children.
speakers: Abhineet Kaul; Aleksandra Chmielewska; Kelly Forbes; Libby Giles; Niki Natrajan
summary_one_liner: Protecting children from AI harms via platform accountability and design
icebreaker: Kelly Forbes on age assurance—how are you currently verifying user age without harming privacy?
networking_tip: Platform Trust leads cluster together; position yourself near speakers post-panel for 1-on-1 compliance discussions.

title: AI in Public Health: Bridging Gaps from Pilots to Sustainable Impact
description: Aligned with the People and Progress Sutras of the India AI Impact Summit 2026, this session examines the barriers and enablers for integrating AI into public health systems at scale. Anchored in the Chakras of AI for Social Good, Democratizing AI Resources, and Resilient Innovation, it addresses the "missing middle" between pilots and adoption, outlining actionable pathways to embed AI healthcare innovations as durable public infrastructure for the Global South.
speakers: Ajay Mahipal; Dr. Deepak Bagla; Himanshu Sikka; Ishita Jain; Mr. CK Mishra; Namrata Mayanil; Nitin Vashisht
summary_one_liner: Crossing the pilot-to-scale gap for AI in public health
icebreaker: Dr. Deepak Bagla on scaling public health AI—what's blocking your pilot's transition to production?
networking_tip: Global health funders + scale-up founders = deal flow. Ask speakers for post-session intros to investors.

title: 'One Billion Futures': AI and the Future of Education Equity in the Global South
description: This session explores how responsible AI can bridge the growing learning and digital divides across the Global South, home to 85% of the world's youth. It focuses on leveraging AI to make education more inclusive, accessible, and equitable for underserved communities.
speakers: Dr.  Shitanshu Mishra; Miral Shah; Neeru Khosla; Paranth Thiruvengadam; Vandana Sikka
summary_one_liner: AI as the great equalizer for one billion Global South learners
icebreaker: Neeru Khosla on bridging learning divides—which Global South region excites you most for EdTech?
networking_tip: Impact investors and EdTech founders both attend. Exchange contacts during group discussions, not after.

title: Great Powers in the Age of AI and Cognitive Systems
description: The session will feature the release and presentation of the report "Great Powers in the Age of AI and Cognitive Systems," highlighting key themes on AI's role in global power structures, governance, and long-term societal impact. A moderated panel will explore AI and cognitive systems in shaping a secure, sustainable future; governance transitions from Industrial to Information Age; India's role; and pathways for responsible innovation and equitable growth.
speakers: Mr. Garry Jacobs; Mr. Glenn Gaffney; Mr. Ketan Patel; Mr. Shaurya Doval
summary_one_liner: Report launch on AI's role in reshaping global power dynamics
icebreaker: Garry Jacobs' report on great powers—how does India's AI strategy shift under cognitive systems?
networking_tip: Geopolitics analysts + national security advisors present—engage during Q&A to signal expertise.

title: Scaling Trusted AI: Global Practices, Local Impact
description: Join senior industry leaders as they showcase enterprise-scale trusted AI adapted for diverse regulatory and market contexts. Moderated by an AI governance expert, the panel will share real-world governance use cases, metrics for measuring trust across geographies, and cross-sector insights. The discussion will highlight practical tools aligned with frameworks such as India's AI Governance Guidelines and explore how proven governance approaches can be localised to scale trusted AI innovation across emerging markets and varied operational contexts.
speakers: Akanksha Ray; Candice Anderson; Caroline Louveaux; Fabrice Ciais; Magesh Bagavathi; Navrina Singh; Rajiv Gupta
summary_one_liner: Credo AI showcases enterprise trust metrics across global markets
icebreaker: Navrina Singh on trusted AI—which regulatory context gave you the biggest compliance surprise?
networking_tip: Governance officers + multinational CIOs here for real-world case studies. Ask panelists for specific client examples.

title: Quality Control of AI Applications in Healthcare
description: Deploy AI models in healthcare through phased pilots, using clinically validated datasets and bias audits. Establish strict data governance, patient consent, and privacy compliance. Implement human-in-the-loop oversight for all clinical decisions. Mandate regulatory approvals, model explainability, and documentation. Conduct continuous performance monitoring, post-deployment audits, and retraining. Define clear accountability, cybersecurity safeguards, and standardized quality benchmarks to ensure safety, accuracy, transparency, and trust in real-world clinical use.
speakers: Lt Col Parikshit Sanyal; Nisheeth Srivastava; Tapan K Gandhi; Taruna Madan Gupta; Vivek Hande
summary_one_liner: Military-grade QC frameworks for clinical AI deployments and audits
icebreaker: Lt Col Parikshit Sanyal on military health AI—how do you balance speed with clinical validation in pilots?
networking_tip: Clinical AI researchers + medical regulators attend. Connect over bias audit methodologies during breaks.

title: AI Vishwaguru: Catalysing Learning and Impact
description: This session will feature the launch of the AI Evidence Playbook, followed by a fireside chat with leaders from civil society and MeitY, Government of India. The discussion will build on the playbook, a practical guide for policymakers and practitioners developing AI-enabled programs, outlining how to identify high-impact use cases and design and evaluate these initiatives. Attendees will receive a digital copy to support the translation of AI policy into practice.
speakers: Abhishek Singh, IAS; Iqbal Dhaliwal"; Maggie Johnson
summary_one_liner: MeitY and J-PAL launch a playbook turning AI policy into practice
icebreaker: Iqbal Dhaliwal's AI Evidence Playbook—how are you measuring impact in your policy interventions?
networking_tip: MeitY officials + J-PAL researchers present. Attend early for 1:1s with government program managers.

title: Social Empowerment via AI Accessibility
description: Explore how accessible AI can empower marginalized communities—covering inclusive design, assistive technologies, low‑bandwidth and local‑language models, community co‑design, and policy frameworks. Sessions highlight scalable solutions, skilling pathways, and cross‑sector partnerships that expand digital participation and economic opportunity.
room: Hall No. 5 First Floor - Session Hall 1
speakers: Ms. Geeta Goel, Head of Global Growth Initiatives, Michael & Susan Dell Foundation; Sh. Tarun Adlakha, Founder & Chief Executive, Ashwath Ventures ; Sh. Ankit Prasad, Founder & CEO, Bobble AI; Sh. Gautam Kumar, Co-Founder & COO, FarEye Technologies; Sh. Gaurav Tripathi, Co-Founder & Group CTO, Partex.AI Tech; Sh. Shayak Mazumder, CEO & CTO, Adya; Sh. Tarun Cherukuri, Founder & CEO, Indus Action
summary_one_liner: Inclusive AI bridges digital divides for marginalized communities at scale
icebreaker: Ankit Prasad of Bobble AI—how are low-bandwidth models reaching India's underserved communities?
networking_tip: Dell Foundation reps here fund social impact AI; emphasize community co-design and measurable outcomes.

title: From Models to Systems: Rethinking the Evaluation of AI in Health
description: AI is increasingly being adopted across health systems, but evidence on safe and equitable use remains fragmented and not consistently aligned with decision-making needs. Existing frameworks often prioritise model performance over real-world interactions with digital infrastructure and contextual factors. This panel will examine methodological gaps in digital health research and discuss a more holistic agenda for AI integration, governance, effectiveness, and equity, concluding with a set of recommendations.
speakers: Arjun Venkatraman; Dr. Mona Duggal; Dr. Smisha Agarwal; Dr. Suruchi Gupta; Mala Kumar; Sameer Pujari; Sarang Deo
knowledge_partners: Center for Global Digital Health Innovation
summary_one_liner: Moving health AI evaluation beyond model accuracy to real-world equity
icebreaker: Dr. Mona Duggal, what's the biggest gap you see between how health systems evaluate AI and what actually matters for safe deployment?
networking_tip: Connect with clinical AI scientists during breaks—they bridge research and real deployment decisions that policymakers need.

title: Powering Quantum Technologies with AI: U.S.–India Collaboration
description: This session aims to explore how AI accelerates quantum technologies while advancing US–India collaboration across research, innovation, and commercialization, aligned with the IndiaAI Mission and National Quantum Mission. It will examine AI–quantum convergence, pathways from lab to market, bilateral cooperation, responsible and secure innovation, and ecosystem needs including infrastructure and talent. The session positions the India AI Summit as a platform for future-defining frontier technologies supporting resilience, innovation, and efficiency.
speakers: Jordan Crenshaw; Mr. Amith Singhee; Mr. Brendan M Peter; Mr. Gopal Ranganathan; Mr. Sandeep Kumar; Priyanka Sharma
summary_one_liner: US-India quantum-AI convergence from lab breakthroughs to commercialization
icebreaker: Amith Singhee, how is the National Quantum Mission approach to AI acceleration different from what US teams are building?
networking_tip: VCs will cluster around quantum researchers—position yourself early if you're exploring deep-tech partnerships.

title: US-India Coordination on Cyber Security and Resilience
description: The US-India cybersecurity alliance is a vital partnership between the world's leading democracies. With both countries sharinng similar threats, coordinated resilience is essential. As AI redefines security, the focus shifts to AI for Cyber—enhancing threat detection—and Cyber for AI—securing AI systems. By building shared frameworks, both nations can protect critical infrastructure, foster innovation, and ensure AI remains a trustworthy foundation for the global digital economy.
speakers: Mr Hari Jayaram; Mr. Abhijeet Gogoi; Mr. Dr Vivek Singh; Mr. Gokul Subramaniam; Mr. Harsh Dhandh; Mr. John W Schaeffler; Mr. K K Singh; Mr. Kishore Balaji; Mr. MAKP Singh; Mr. Narendra Nath
knowledge_partners: The American Chamber of Commerce in India (AMCHAM India)
summary_one_liner: US-India cyber alliance tackles AI-era threat detection and infrastructure defense
icebreaker: John W Schaeffler, how are CISOs rethinking threat detection now that AI has redefined the threat landscape?
networking_tip: CISOs attend for peer intel sharing—ask about specific infrastructure challenges they're solving, not general trends.

title: AI for the Global South: From Governance to Inclusion
description: This high-level roundtable convenes parliamentarians, diplomats, multilateral organizations, and technology governance experts to facilitate a strategic dialogue on shaping an inclusive global AI agenda rooted in the developmental priorities of the Global South. Participants will explore frameworks for multilateral cooperation and examine how legislative and regulatory ecosystems can encourage responsible AI innovation in critical domains including healthcare, agriculture, education, and social protection, ensuring that AI adoption broadly supports equitable access and drives inclusive development.
speakers: Ambassador  Dr. Lavina Ramkissoon; Ambassador Eugênio Vargas Garcia; Dr. Sasmit Patra; S. Niranjan Reddy; Trisha Ray
summary_one_liner: Ambassadors and parliamentarians shape an inclusive Global South AI agenda
icebreaker: Ambassador Lavina Ramkissoon, what's the one AI governance blind spot you see across the Global South?
networking_tip: High-density decision-makers—research attendees beforehand and request 1:1s with diplomats and multilateral org leaders.

title: Flipping the Script: How the Global Majority Can Recode the AI Economy
description: This session will examine how countries in the Global Majority can reshape the AI economy by moving from adoption to agency. It will explore practical pathways for ethical, inclusive, and economically viable AI ecosystems. Through policy dialogue and audience exchange, the discussion will highlight data governance, infrastructure, talent, and standards as levers of sovereignty, and will outline concrete models for South–South cooperation to build resilient, value-sharing AI futures.
speakers: Kazim Rizvi; Philip Thigo; Rachel Adams; Reggie Townsend; Vrushali Sawant
summary_one_liner: Global Majority nations reclaim agency in the AI economy via sovereignty
icebreaker: Kazim Rizvi, which Global Majority countries are closest to building genuine AI agency vs. just better adoption?
networking_tip: Policy strategists and think tank researchers attend—find them in smaller breakout sessions for deeper governance conversations.

title: Local Voices First: Why Inclusive AI for Data Systems Must Start on the Ground
description: The session examines how AI can better serve citizens when grounded in local data ecosystems, languages, and institutional realities. Through expert insights, it highlights co-created, inclusive AI as public infrastructure for official statistics, featuring innovations from the Global South and national institutions. The panel discussion shows how locally rooted approaches enhance relevance, legitimacy, and trust in data-driven governance, strengthening evidence-based policymaking and responsive public services.
speakers: Amitabh Nag; Gaurav Godhwani; Johannes Jütting; Mercedes Fogarassy; Saachi Bhalla; Saurabh Garg
summary_one_liner: OECD-backed panel grounds AI in local data ecosystems and languages
icebreaker: Johannes Jütting from OECD, how can local data ecosystems compete when centralized AI systems already have scale?
networking_tip: National statisticians are data gatekeepers—connect early and show how your approach respects local institutional realities.

title: Teacher-Led, Localised and Frugal AI for Equitable Education in the Commonwealth
description: This session operationalizes the Gaborone Statement by presenting practical pathways for "Teacher-in-the-Loop" AI and localized, open-source LLM deployments. Commonwealth ministers and leaders will examine policy, capacity, and governance to enable frugal, sovereign, and inclusive AI in education, specifically for lower-resource settings. Key outcomes include adopting the "Gaborone → Delhi Compact," identifying pilot collaborations, publishing a sovereign education-AI reference architecture, and establishing monitorable indicators for 12-month follow-up.
speakers: Dr Basheerhamad Shadrach; Dr Edwin Tarno; Dr Rajni Kaushal Chand; Dr Sawkat Rojid; Dr Sumit Kalra; Dr The Honourable Ismail Shafeeu; Prof. Ganesan Kannabiran; Professor Ami Upadhyay; Professor Peter Scott
summary_one_liner: Commonwealth ministers adopt frugal, teacher-in-the-loop AI for education
icebreaker: Prof. Ganesan Kannabiran, what does 'teacher-in-the-loop' actually look like when you deploy it in Commonwealth schools?
networking_tip: Education ministers attend—reach out via event organizers pre-event; they rarely have office hours but value direct invitations.

title: Building India's AI Governance Architecture: From Frameworks to Implementation
description: This session will explore how India can build mission driven institutions to govern artificial intelligence at national scale. It will examine emerging approaches to AI governance and expert mechanisms, drawing lessons from successful public digital institutions. The discussion will focus on balancing innovation with accountability, clarifying institutional mandates, and enabling sustained collaboration across government, industry, startups, and research to translate AI strategy into effective, responsible execution.
speakers: Dr. Vivek Raghavan; Keita Nishiyama; Mr. Amandeep Gill; Mr. Amitabh Kant; Mr. Gaurav Aggarwal; Mr. Hugo Valadares; Prof. Ramesh Raskar
summary_one_liner: Amitabh Kant and Amandeep Gill architect India's national AI governance
icebreaker: Amitabh Kant, which institutional design for AI governance do you think India will actually institutionalize first?
networking_tip: Senior officials present—connect through G20 Sherpa network members or MIT Media Lab researchers for warm intros.

title: The Sociotechnical Turn in AI Governance: Bridging Theory and Practice
description: This session will explore how sociotechnical approaches to artificial intelligence can move from theory to real-world governance practice. It will examine how social context, power, trust, and institutional design shape AI risks and outcomes beyond purely technical solutions. Bringing together research and practice, the discussion will focus on translating sociotechnical insights into actionable frameworks for safe and trusted AI, with particular relevance for public sector deployment and Global South contexts.
speakers: Dr. Siddharth Mehrotra; H.E. Hendrikus G.J. (Harry) Verweij; Kirthi Jayakumar; Lisa Gotoh; Prof. Maarten de Rijke; Prof. Virginia Dignum
summary_one_liner: Virginia Dignum leads the push from AI ethics theory to governance practice
icebreaker: Prof. Virginia Dignum, how do sociotechnical approaches change what an EU AI Act compliance team should actually be doing?
networking_tip: Responsible AI officers attend—they're stretched thin, so offer specific, actionable insights rather than abstract theory.

title: Culture and Code: Creative AI for Equitable Development
description: The session will deliberate on the role of Artificial Intelligence in democratizing creativity and advancing inclusion, while addressing concerns related to authenticity, ethical use, and equity. It will explore how AI can broaden access to creative expression, along with the safeguards needed to ensure its contributions support responsible and inclusive development.
speakers: . Ms. Siok Siok Tan; Mr. Shekhar Kapur; Ms. Jaya Deshmukh; Prof. Olivier Oullier; Vilas Dhar
summary_one_liner: Shekhar Kapur explores how generative AI democratizes creative expression
icebreaker: Shekhar Kapur, how do you think about authenticity when AI remixes culture at scale?
networking_tip: Creative industry and media execs cluster together—approach them with specific use cases, not general creative AI pitches.

title: Governing Autonomy: Agentic AI, Multi-Agent Systems, and the Infrastructure of Trust
description: This session will be focused on addressing governance gaps in emerging agentic and multi-agent AI systems. The session will introduce a new public–private governance framework and showcase the Agentic AI Governance Stack through a live demonstration, followed by expert's discussion on safe autonomy, accountability, and standards. It will conclude with the launch of a global Agentic AI Testbed, inviting multi-stakeholder collaboration led by India's DPI strengths.
speakers: Alpesh Shah; Amir Banifatemi; Apoorva Goyal; Ellie Sakhaee; Praveen Tanguturi; Ramesh Raskar
knowledge_partners: Cognizant - Responsible AI Office and AI Lab
summary_one_liner: Live demo of Agentic AI Governance Stack with global testbed launch
icebreaker: Ramesh Raskar's AI testbed sounds fascinating—what governance gaps are you seeing in your agentic systems?
networking_tip: High decision-maker density means target the breaks—chat with AI Platform Engineers about real infrastructure challenges they're solving.

title: AI-Driven Digital Transformation for India: Building Innovation an Ecosystem through Collaboration
description: This session brings together leaders from government, industry, startups, and academia to discuss democratizing AI infrastructure for innovation. The session explores how accessible AI infrastructure can empower startups, MSMEs, and researchers, and how collaborative national models can sustain growth. It highlights the value of open repositories, shared use cases across sectors, and open-source platforms, while emphasizing ethical, inclusive AI design that prioritizes privacy, fairness and accessibility to help India lead global AI innovation.
speakers: Abhilash Soundararajan; Akhil Gupta; Akhilesh Tuteja; Anisha Singh; Dr. Tapan Sahoo; Rohan Chhatwal
summary_one_liner: Maruti Suzuki-backed forum on democratizing AI infra for MSMEs and startups
icebreaker: How is Maruti Suzuki's approach to AI infrastructure changing what you're building for MSMEs?
networking_tip: Manufacturing and startup founders in one room—find the MSME leaders during Q&A and ask about their biggest infrastructure gap.

title: Democratizing AI Resources in India
description: As India emerges as a regional AI leader in South Asia, this session will explore how business-driven AI, combined with India's digital public infrastructure, startup innovation and cloud-led transformation, can deliver inclusive and commercially viable social impact. The discussion will highlight how scalable AI adoption across SMEs and startups can democratise resources, expand access to services, create equitable opportunities, and showcase India's model of cross-border collaboration, inclusive use cases and knowledge sharing for sustainable growth.
speakers: Dr. Chris Merz; Dr. Lovneesh Chanana; Mandar Kulkarn; Manoj Paul; Mr. Sunil Gupta; Ms. Subi Chaturvedi; Puneet Chandok; Ranganath Sadasiva; Sandeep Dutta; Sandip Patel
knowledge_partners: The Associated Chambers of Commerce & Industry of India (ASSOCHAM)
summary_one_liner: ASSOCHAM convenes cloud and startup leaders to democratize India's AI stack
icebreaker: Puneet Chandok's cloud vision + digital public infra—what's the real blocker for SMEs to adopt AI right now?
networking_tip: 10 speakers means mini-breakouts likely. Circle the Cloud Platform Executives and Series A founders between sessions.

title: Reskilling for Tomorrow: AI, Sustainability, and India's Jobs Transition
description: India's move toward a green and digital economy is reshaping jobs, skills, and employer expectations. This panel examines how AI and automation can support skill mapping, personalised training, and workforce transitions—while addressing challenges of access, trust, and inequality. Policymakers, industry, training providers, and technology experts will discuss how India can prepare workers for emerging green and tech-enabled roles and build inclusive, future-ready skilling systems.
speakers: Dr Arunabha Ghosh; Dr Claire Melamed; Mr Nirmit Parikh; Ms Aditi Jha; Ms Sabina Dewan
knowledge_partners: Council on Energy Environment and Water (CEEW)
summary_one_liner: CEEW maps how AI powers India's green-jobs transition and workforce reskilling
icebreaker: Dr. Claire Melamed's green jobs angle—how are you rethinking workforce transition in your sector?
networking_tip: CHROs and Skilling Platform Founders won't overlap much elsewhere. Arrive early to claim seat near policy researchers.

title: Founders & Funders: The India AI Capital Ecosystem
description: The session will convene senior policymakers, global investors, and leading AI architects to discuss India's roadmap for building AI for the world. Conversations will span the full stack—from compute and semiconductor foundations to the "AI Alpha" that guides frontier investment decisions. The dialogue will focus on designing foundational models and scaling India's intelligence infrastructure for global impact. From silicon to superintelligence, the session will chart India's pathway to long-term AI leadership.
speakers: ⁠⁠Aakrit Vaish; Mohit Bhatnagar; Pratyush Kumar; S. Krishnan; Sharad Sanghi; ⁠Vinod Khosla
summary_one_liner: Vinod Khosla and Peak XV chart India's AI investment and compute roadmap
icebreaker: Vinod Khosla on India's compute stack—what's your bet on foundational models vs. applications?
networking_tip: Heavy-hitter event with VCs + founders. Work the room before talks; after keynotes everyone clusters. Grab Aakrit Vaish early.

title: AI in Climate and Agriculture: Building Resilient Communities
description: How can AI based technologies strengthen climate resilience and reduce impacts of climate shocks for vulnerable households? This session, featuring a presentation by an international researcher on findings from a randomised evaluation of the impact of AI-based flood Early Warning Systems (EWS), followed by a panel discussion with leading experts. Building on this evidence, panellists explore how rigorously evaluated AI applications can support effective climate adaptation strategies, improve preparedness, and translate technological innovations into accelerating climate action.
speakers: George Richards; Maulik Jagnani
summary_one_liner: Rigorous RCT evidence on AI flood early-warning systems for climate resilience
icebreaker: George Richards' J-PAL RCT on flood prediction—what climate risk are you tackling with AI?
networking_tip: Low decision-maker density but deep expertise. Find the Agritech Researchers and DFI reps; they're your connectors to bigger deals.

title: AI Masterclass in Enterprise Operations
description: This session, facilitated by Tata Communications, is focused on guiding participants from isolated AI initiatives to the implementation of secure, scalable AI solutions across their enterprise operations. Designed for technology and transformation leaders, this hands-on workshop enables participants to design and deploy a fully functional AI Worker using the Tata Communications Agent Builder platform, providing them with direct experience and a practical framework for integrating AI into their enterprise workflows.
speakers: Vasant Srinivasan
summary_one_liner: Hands-on Tata workshop: build and deploy an AI Worker in 90 minutes
icebreaker: Vasant Srinivasan's Tata Communications AI agent builder—how are you scaling from pilot to enterprise deployment?
networking_tip: Hands-on workshop = smaller group, more direct access. Sit near CTOs during breaks; they influence procurement decisions.

title: Global Capital, Local Advantage: India in the AI Race
description: India's AI opportunity is global: products can be built locally and sold worldwide, but leadership depends on translating India's strengths-talent, digital infrastructure, and cost-efficient execution-into scalable applications. This session spotlights where India can lead across the AI value chain, focusing on sectors like financial services and insurance, where AI transforms underwriting, claims, and risk. It will examine sovereign AI-autonomy in models, data, and compute-and how cross-domain investments can accelerate India's advantage.
speakers: Sriram Viswanathan; Abhishek Shukla; Sanjay Tugnait; Dipender Saluja; Shereen Bhan
summary_one_liner: Celesta Capital maps where India wins in the global AI value chain
icebreaker: Sriram Viswanathan—what gives Indian fintech AI startups an edge in global markets?
networking_tip: Cross-border VCs and Series B+ founders mingle here; have your go-to-market strategy for global customers.

title: Consumers at the Core: Building AI with Consumer-Centric Approach
description: AI has seen rapid evolution from being a technological tool for consumers performing simple tasks to generative AI with predictive and prescriptive power. Developing AI technologies with a consumer-centric approach is crucial for building consumer trust, inclusion and satisfaction. The panel discussion, 'Consumers at the Core: Building AI with a Consumer-Centric Approach', will focus on the evolving AI ecosystem, the concerns and innovation possibilities of AI with a focus on protecting consumer interest.
speakers: Mr. Ashim Sanyal; Mr. Kaushal Mahan; Mr. Rohit Kumar Singh; Mr. Sudeep Das; Ms. Anindita Mehta; Ms. Erin Parsons; Ms. Sarita Chauhan
summary_one_liner: Consumer protection meets generative AI: trust, inclusion, and regulatory design
icebreaker: Ms. Erin Parsons on consumer protection—how do you balance innovation speed with trust in your product?
networking_tip: Product Managers + Legal Officers rarely meet. Find the intersection—ask about real trust challenges in consumer AI rollouts.

title: AI for Humanity as SDG#18: Towards Global and Sustainable Development of AI with Impact
description: This session advances the concept of "AI for Humanity" as the invisible SDG 18, recognizing AI as a cross-cutting enabler of all Sustainable Development Goals. Building on previous discussions, it brings global experts together to explore human-centered, inclusive, and sustainable AI frameworks. Through keynotes and panel dialogue, the session aims to reinforce global collaboration and sustain impact beyond 2026 via policy, practice, and multistakeholder engagement.
speakers: Dr. James Ong; Judith Weinberger-Singh; Maya Sherman; Sameer Gahlot; Tan Siok Siok; Vibhav Mithal
summary_one_liner: Proposing AI as the 18th SDG to anchor humanity-first global frameworks
icebreaker: Dr. James Ong's SDG 18 concept—which SDG is AI making the biggest impact on in your work?
networking_tip: UN SDG + Social Enterprise founders = mission-driven crowd. Shift from pitch to purpose; ask about partnerships over funding.

title: Leveraging AI in Education: Human Capital, Inclusion, and Trust in the AI Era.
description: This panel discussion explores how artificial intelligence is reshaping education, with a focus on human capital development, inclusion, and trust. Panelists will reflect on the opportunities AI presents for improving access and learning outcomes, while also addressing concerns around bias, governance, and public confidence. Drawing on policy, practice, and lived experience, the discussion aims to highlight practical insights on aligning AI adoption in education with inclusive and socially trusted outcomes.
speakers: Ajit Chauhan; Dr. Prabina Rajib; Dr. Subhajyoti Ray,; Param Jeet; Prakash Tiwary; Preet Deep Singh; Shreevats Jaipuria; Vishal Talwar
summary_one_liner: Higher-ed leaders align AI adoption with inclusion, trust, and learning outcomes
icebreaker: Shreevats, how are B-schools approaching AI literacy for future HR leaders?
networking_tip: Connect with HR Skilling Leaders during breaks—they're actively building AI programs now.

title: AI for Medical Imaging and Clinical Diagnostics
description: The AI for Medical Imaging and Clinical Diagnostics session at the India AI Impact Summit 2026 will explore how AI is transforming healthcare diagnostics. The expert panel will discuss advances in medical imaging, real-world clinical deployment, precision and predictive diagnostics, and responsible AI practices. The session brings together clinicians, AI researchers, and policymakers to strengthen India's healthcare AI ecosystem.
speakers: Dr. Alok Sharma; Dr. Kundan Singh Chufal; Prof. Chandan J. Das; Prof. M. K. Dutta; Prof. Nidhi Goel; Prof. Sujeet Gautam
summary_one_liner: Clinicians and AI researchers advance precision medical imaging diagnostics in India
icebreaker: Prof. Das, what's the biggest skill gap you're seeing in medical imaging AI roles?
networking_tip: Arrive early to access radiologists and healthtech founders before technical sessions get dense.

title: Faculty Futures 2035: Global Roadmap for Human-Centred AI Education
description:
As AI reshapes teaching, assessment, and governance, higher education faces a
shared challenge: preparing faculty for ethical, inclusive, and human-centered
engagement. Following pre-summit workshops conducted in Canada, Australia,
and India, the Faculty Futures 2035 panel convenes partners at the India AI Impact
Summit 2026 to synthesize insights, surface cross-context lessons, and present a
forward-looking roadmap to guide institutional strategy for the decade ahead.
speakers: Dr. Aigerim (Aia) Shilibekova; Dr. Amandeep Sehmi; Dr. Amit Kumar Mishra; Dr. Pranil Prasad; Dr. Sana Jamil; Dr. Sandra Song; Dr. Thipendra P Singh
summary_one_liner: Cross-continental roadmap prepares faculty for human-centered AI pedagogy by 2035
icebreaker: Dr. Sehmi, what's one AI pedagogy shift you'd recommend universities start with today?
networking_tip: Faculty are collaborative—sit with international education partners to explore curriculum partnerships.

title: Driving Financial Resilience and Sustainable Impact - AI by and for the Global Majority
description: While the world focuses on the technical capabilities of AI, we are largely overlooking the financial architecture required to sustain it. Meaningful scale in health and agriculture cannot happen unless we position financial resilience as an equal pillar of success. This panel will discuss how governments, investors, philanthropies, the private sector and technology leaders can align capital and innovation pathways to ensure AI delivers lasting impact.
speakers: Dr. Alaa Murabit; Dr. Michael Kremer; Elizabeth Kelly; Sanjay Jain; Shankar Maruwada
summary_one_liner: Nobel laureate Kremer and 500 Global align capital for AI-driven social impact
icebreaker: Sanjay, how are impact investors evaluating financial sustainability in AI health startups?
networking_tip: This is high-density decision-maker crowd—prep specific pitches and use lunch for 1-on-1 investor meetings.

title: AI for Economic Growth and Social Good | AI for All: Driving Economic Advancement and Societal Well-Being
description: This session explores how AI ambitions can be translated into scalable economic value and inclusive social impact. Leaders from government, industry, and policy will examine AI adoption across public services, finance, cybersecurity, and data governance, with a focus on responsible AI, digital public infrastructure, and workforce readiness. The discussion highlights collaboration models to enable trusted, high-impact AI at a national scale.
speakers: Dr. Avik Sarkar; Dr. Gulshan Rai; Mr. Dhrubabrata Ghosh; Mr. Mohit Kapoor; Mr. Rajeev Mishra; Mr. Sachin Tayal
summary_one_liner: Protiviti-led panel translates responsible AI into scalable economic and social value
icebreaker: Dr. Rai, what's your priority for upskilling CIOs in responsible AI governance?
networking_tip: Enterprise strategists cluster around case studies—ask speakers for intro to peers tackling similar challenges.
